editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Widdow Ranter OR, The HISTORY of Bacon in Virginia. A TRAGI-COMEDY, Acted by their Majesties Servants.
Written by Mrs. A. Behn.
LONDON, Printed for James Knapton at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-Yard. 1690.

div.head: To the much Honoured Madam Welldon.
div.p: KNowing Mrs. Behn in her Life-time design'd to Dedicate some of of her Works to you, you ha •… e a Naturall Title, and claim to this and I could not wi •… hout being unjust to her Memory, but fix your name to it, who ha •… e not only a Wit above that, of most of your Sex; but a goodness and Affability Extreamly Charming, and Engaging beyond Measure, and perhaps there are few to be found like you, that are so Eminent for Hospitallity, and a Ready and Generous Assistance to the distress'd and Indigent, which are Quallities that carry much more of Divinity with them, then a Puritanicall outward Zeal for Virtue and Religion.

Our Author, Madam, who was so true a Judge of Wit, was (no doubt of it) satisfyed in the Patroness she had pitcht upon: If ever she had occasion for a Wit and Sense like yours 'tis now, to Defend this (one of the last of her Works) from the Malice of her Enemies, and the ill Nature of the Critticks, who have had Ingratitude enough not to Consider the Obligations they had to her when Living; but to do those Gentlemen Justice, 'tis not (altogether) to be Imputed to their Critticism, that the Play had not that Success which it deserv'd, and was expected by her Friends; The main fault ought to lye on those who had the management of it. Had our Authour been alive she would have Committed it to the Flames rather than have suffer'd it to have been Acted with such Omissions as was made, and on which the Foundation of the Play Depended: For Example, they thought fit to leave out a Whole Scene of the Virginian Court of Judicature, which was a lively resemblance of that Country-Justice; and on which depended a great part of the Plot, and wherein were many unusuall and very Naturall J •… sts which would at least have made some sort of People laugh: In another Part of the Play is Omitted the appearance of the Ghost of the Indian King, Kill'd by Bacon, and tho' the like may have been Represented in other Plays, yet I never heard or found but that the sight was very agreeable to an Audience, and very Awfull: besi des the Apparition of the Ghost was necessary, for it was that which struck a Terror
in the Queen, and fright'ned her from heark'ning to the Love of Bacon, believing it a horrid thing to receive the Caresses and Embraces of her Husbands Murderer: And Lastly, many of the Parts being false Cast, and given to those whose Tallants and Genius's suited not our Authors Intention: These, Madam, are some of the Reasons that this Play was unsuccessfull, and the best Play that ever was writ must prove so: if it have the Fate to be Murder'd like this.

However, Madam, I can't but believe you will find an hours diversion in the reading, and will meet with not only Wit, but true Comedy, (tho' low,) by reason many of the Characters are such only as our Newgate afforded, being Criminals Transported.

This Play, Madam, being left in my hands by the Author to Introduce to the Publick, I thought my self oblig'd to say thus much in its defence, and that it was also a Duty upon me to choose 〈◊〉 Patroness proper for it, and the Author having pitcht upon your name to do Honour to some of her Works, I thought your Protection, could be so usefull to none, as to this, whose owning it may Silence the Malice of its Enemies; Your Wit and Judgment being to be Submitted to in all Cases; Besides your Natural Tenderness and Compassion for the Unfortunate, gives you in a manner another Title to it: The preference which is due to you upon so many Accounts is therefore the Reason of this present Address, for at the worst, if this Play should be so Unfortunate as not to be thought worthy of your Acceptance; Yet it is certain, that its worth any Man's while to have the Honour of subscribing himself,

closer.signed: Your Most Obedient Humble Servant, G. J.

Mr. Powell. Friendly.
Two Friends known to one another many years in England.

Mr. Sandford. Dareing
Mr. Cudworth. Fearless.
Lieutenant Generals to Bacon

Mr. Blunt. A Petitioner against Brag.
Mr. Baker. Parson Dunce, formerly a Farrier •… led from England, And Chaplain to the Governour.
Mrs. Bra •… girdle,Indian Queen, call'd Semernia, belov'd by Bacon.
Mrs. Knight. Madam Surelove: belov'd by Hazard.
Mrs. Jordon. Mrs. Crisante. Daughter to Col. Down.
Mrs. Currer.Wid. Ranter in Love with Dareing.

div.p: Mrs. Whimsey. Mrs. Whiff. 2. Maids. Priests, Indians, Coachman, Soldiers, with other Attendants.
SCENE Virginia in Bacons Camp.

div.head: Books Newly Printed for James Knapton, at the Crown in St. Paul's-Church-Yard.
div.p: A Congratulatory Poem on his Highness the Prince of Orange's coming into England. By Tho. Shadwell.
A Congratulatory Poem to the Most Illustrious Queen Mary, upon Her Arrival into England. By Tho. Shadwell.

The Squire of Alsatia. A Comedy Acted by their Majesties Servants. Written by
•… ho Shadwell.
Bury Fair. A Comedy, Acted by Their Majesties Servants. Written by Tho. Shadwell.
A True Widow. A Comedy, Acted by their Majesties Servants. Written by Tho. Shadwell.
The Fortune-Hunters, O •… , Two Fools well-met. A Comedy, as it is Acted by their Majesties Servants. Written by James Carlile,
The Forced Marriage, Or, the Jealous Bridegroom: As it is Acted by their Majesties Servants. Written by A. Behn.
The Female Prelate: Being a History of the Life and Death of Pope Joan: A Tragedy, As it is Acted at the Theatre-Royall.
Mr. Anthony. A Comedy. Acted by their Majesties Servants. Written by the Right Honourable the Earl of Orrery.
The Governour of Cyprus, or, the Lovers of Virotto, and Dorothea. A Novel in Twelves.
The Wanton Fryar, or, the Irish Amour, First and Second Part. A Novel in Twelves.

The History of the Inquisition, as it is Exercised at Goa; Written in French by the Ingenious Monsieur De •… on, who laboured five years under those Severities, With an Account of his Deliverance; translated into English. Quarto. Price 1
〈◊〉 .

Some Observations concerning Regulating of Elections for Parliament, found among the Earl of Shaftsbury's Papers after his Death, and now recommended to the Consideration of the present Parliament. In Quarto. price 3d.
Quadriennium Jacobi, or, the History of the Reign of King James II. from his first coming to the Crown to his Desertion.

lg.l: HEav'n save ye Gallants: and this hopefull Age,
Y' are welcome to the downfall of the Stage:
The Fools have labour'd long in their Vocation;
And Vice, (the Manufacture of the Nation)
O're-stocks the Town so much, and thrives so well,
That Fopps and Knaves grow Druggs and will not sell▪
In vain our Wares on Theatres are shown,
When each has a Plantation of his own.
His Cause ne'r fails; for whatsoe're he spends,
There's still Gods plenty for himself and Friends.
Shou'd Men be rated by Poetick Rules,
Lord what a Pole would there be rais'd from Fools!
Mean time poor Wit prohibited must lye,
As if'twere made some French Commodity.
Fools you will have, and rais'd at vast expence,
And yet as soon as seen, they give offence.
Time was, when none would cry that Oaf was m •… ,
But now you strive about your Pedigree:
Bawble and Cap no sooner are thrown down,
But there's a Muss of more then half the Town.
Each one will challenge a Child's part at least,
A sign •… e Family is well increas'd
Of Forreign Cattle! there's no longer need,
When w'are supply'd so fast with English Breed.
W •… ll! Flourish, Countrymen: drink swear and roar,
Let every free-born Subject keep his Whore;
And wandring in the Wilderness about,
At end of 40 years not wear her out.
But when you see these Pictures let none dare
To own beyond a Limb or single share:

F •…
•… here the Punk is common! he's a Sot,
〈◊〉 needs will Father what the Parish go •… .
GAllants you have so long been absent hence,
That you have almost cool'd your dilligence,
For while we study or revive a Play,
You like good Husbands in the Country stay,
There frugally wear out your Summer Suite,
And in Frize Jerkin after Beagles Toot,
Or in Mon •… tero Caps at field-fares shoot,
Nay some are so obdurate in their Sin,
That they swear never to come up again.
But all their charge of Cloathes and treat Retrench,
To Gloves and Stockings for some Country Wench.
Even they who in the Summer had mishaps,
Send up to Town for Physick for their Claps.
The Ladyes too are as resolv'd as they,
And having debts unknown to them, they stay,
And with the gain of Cheese and Poultry pay.
Even in their Visits, they from Banquets fall,
To entertain with Nuts and bottle Ale.
And in discourse with secresy report
Stale-News that past a Twelve-month since at Court.
Those of them who are most refin'd, and gay,
Now learn the Songs of the last Summers Pl •… y:
While the young Daughter does in private Mour •… ,
Her Loves in Town, and hopes not to return.
These Country grievances too great appear;
But cruell Ladies, we have greater here;
You come not sharp as you were wont to Playes;
But only on the first and second Days:
This made our Poet, in his visits look
What new strange courses, for your time you took.
And to his great regret he found too soon,
Basset and Umbre, spent the afternoon:
So that we cannot hope to see you here
Before the little Net work Purse be clear.
Suppose you should have luck;—
Yet sitting up so late as I am told,
You'l loose in Beauty, what you win in Gold:
And what each Lady of another says,
Will make you new Lampoons, and us new Plays.

div.head: SCENE I. A Room with severall Tables.
div.stage: Enter Hazard in a Travelling Habit, and a Sea-Boy Carrying his Port-mantle.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: WHat Town's this Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: James-Town, Master,

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Take care my Trunk be brought ashore to Night, and there's for your Pains.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: God bless you Master.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: What do you call this House?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Mrs Flirts, Master, the best House for Commendation in all Virginia.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: That's well, has she any handsome Lady's Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Oh! She's woundly handsome her self Master, and the Kindest Gentlewoman—look here she comes Master—God bless you Mistriss, I have brought you a young Gentleman here.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: That's well, honest Jack—Sir, you are most heartily Welcome.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Madam, your Servant;

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Please you to walk into a Chamber Sir.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: By and by, Madam, but I'le repose here a while for the coolness of the Air.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: This is a Publick Room, Sir, but 'tis at your Service.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Madam, you oblige me.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: A Fine-spoken Person—A Gentleman I'le warrant him, come Jack, I'le give thee a Cogue of Brandy for old acquaintance.
sp.stage: Hazard Pulls out Pen, Ink and Paper, and goes to Write.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Here Nell, a Tankard of Cool drink quickly.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: You shall have it, Sr.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hah! who's that Stranger? he seems to be a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: If I should give Credit to mine Eyes, that should be Friendly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sr, you seem a stranger, may I take the Liberty to present my Service to you?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p:
If I am not mistaken Sr, you are the only Man in the world
whom I would soonest Pledge, you'l Credit me if three years Absence has not made you forget Hazard.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hazard, my Freind! come to my Arms and Heart.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: This Unexpected Happiness O're-Joys me. Who could have Imagin'd to have found thee in Virginia? I thought thou hadst been in Spain with thy Brother.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I was so till Ten Months since, when my Uncle Colonell Frendly dying here, left me a Considerable Plantation; And faith I find Diversions not altogether to be despis'd; the God of Love Reigns here, with as much Power, as in Courts or Popular Cities: but prethee what Chance, (Fortunate for me) drove thee to this part of the New World?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Why (faith) Ill Company, and that Common Vice of the Town, Gaming, soon run out my Younger Brothers Fortune, for Imagining like some of the Luckier Gamesters to Improve my Stock at the Groom-Porters; Ventur'd on and lost all—My Elder Brother an Errant Jew, had neither Friendship, nor Honour enough to Support me, but at last was mollified by perswasions and the hopes of being for ever rid of me, sent me hither with a small Cargo to seek my fortune,—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And begin the world withall.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I thought this a better Venture then to turn Sharping Bully, Cully in Prentices and Country Squires, with my Pocket full of false dice, your high and low Flats and Bars, or turn broker to young Heirs; take up goods, to pay ten fold at the Death of their Fathers, and take Fees on both sides; or set up all night at the Groom Porters begging his Honour to go a Guinney the better of the lay. No. Friendly, I had rather starve abroad then live Pitty'd and dispised at home.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou art in the Right, and art come just in the Nick of time to make thy Fortune—Wilt thou follow my advice?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Thou art too honest to Command any thing any thing that I shall Refuse.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You must know then, there is about a Mil •… from James Town a Young Gentlewoman—No matter for her Birth, her Breeding's the best this world affords, she is Marryed to one of the Richest Merchants here, he is Old and Sick, and now gone into England for the Recovery of his Health, where he'l e'e •… give up the Ghost, he has writ her word he finds no Amendment, and Resolves to stay another Year, the Letter I accidently took up and have about me; 'tis easily Counterfeited and will be of great use to us.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Now do I fancy I conceive thee.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, hear me first, you shall get another Letter writ like this Character, which shall say, you are his Kinsman, that is come to Trafick in this Country, and 'tis his will you should be received into his House as such.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Well, and what will come of this?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Why thou ar •… Young and Handsome; She Young and De •…
ring; 〈◊〉 were easy to make her Love thee, and if the Old Gentleman chance to dye, you Guess the rest, you are no Fool.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Ay, but if he shou'd return—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If—Why if she Love you, that Other will be but a slender Bar to thy happiness; For if thou canst not Marry her, thou mayst lye with her, (and Gad) a Younger Brother may pick out a Pritty Livelyhood here that way, as well as in England—Or if this •… ail, there thou wilt find a perpetual Visiter the Widdow Ranter, a Woman bought from the Ship by Old Coll. Ranter; she serv'd him half a year, and then he Marry'd her, and dying in a year more, left her worth Fifty thousand Pounds Sterling, besides Plate and Jewells: She's a great Gallant, But assuming the Humour of the Country Gentry, her Extravagancy is very Pleasant, she retains something of her Primitive Quallity still, but is good natur'd and Generous.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I like all this well.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But I have a further End in this matter, you must know there is in the same House a Young Heiress, one Coll. Downrights Daughter, whom I Love, I think not in Vain, her Father indeed has an Implacable hatred to me, for which Reason I can but seldom Visit her, and in this Affair I have need of a Friend in that House.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Me you're sure of.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And thus you'l have an Opportunity to Mannage both our Amours: here you will find Occasion to shew your Courage as well as Express your Love; For at this time the Indians by our ill Management of Trade, whom we have Armed against Our selves, Very frequently make War upon us with our own Weapons, Tho' often coming by the Worst are forced to make Peace with us again, but so, as upon every turn they fall to Massacring us whereever we ly exposed to them.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I heard the news of this in England, which hastens the new Governours arrivall here, who brings you fresh Supplys.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Would he were landed, we hear he is a Noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: He has all the Qualities of a Gallant Man, besides he is Nobly Born.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This Country wants nothing but to be People'd with a wellborn Race to make it one of the best Collonies in the World, but for want of a Governour we are Ruled by a Councill, some of which have been perhaps transported Criminals, who having Acquired great Estates are now become your Honour, and Right Worshipfull, and Possess all Places of Authority; there are amongst 'em some honest Gentlemen who now begin to take upon 'em, and Manage Affairs as they ought to be.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Bacon I think was one of the Councill.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Now you have named a Man indeed above the Common Rank, by Nature Generous; Brave Resolv'd, and Daring; who studying the Lives of the Romans and great Men, that have raised themselves to the most Elevated fortunes, fancies it easy for Ambitious men, to aim at any Pitch of Glory, I've heard him often say, Why cannot I Conquer the Universe as well as Alexander? or like another Romulus form a new Rome, and make my self Ador'd?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Why might he not? great Souls are born in common men, sometimes as well as Princes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This Thirst of Glory cherisht by Sullen Melancholly, I believe was the first Motive that made him in Love with the young Indian-Queen, fancying no Hero ought to be without his Princess. And this was the Reason why he so earnestly prest for a Commission, to be made General against the Indians, which long was promis'd him, but they fearing his Ambition, still put him off, till the Grievances grew so high, that the whole Country flockt to him, and beg'd he would redress them,—he took the opportunity, and Led them forth to fight, and vanquishing brought the Enemy to fair terms, but now instead of receiving him as a Conquerour, we treat him as a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Then it seems all the Crime this brave Fellow has committed, is serving his Country without Authority.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Tis so, and however I admire the Man, I am resolv'd to be of the Contrary Party, that I may make an Interest in our new Governour; Thus stands-affairs, so that after you have seen Madam Sure-Love, I'le present you to the Councill for a Commission.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: But my Kinsmans Character—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: He was a Lester-shire younger Brother, came over hither with a small fortune, which his Industry has increas'd to a thousand pound a year, and he is now Coll. John Sure-love, and one of the Councill.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: About it then, Madam Flirt to direct you.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: You are full of your Madams here.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Oh! 'tis the greatest affront imaginable, to all a woman Mistris, tho' but a retale Brandy-munger.—Adieu •… —one thing more, tomorrow is our Country-Court, pray do not fa •… l to be there, for the rarity of the Entertainment: but I shall see you anon at Sure-lo •…
where I'le Salute thee as my first meeting, and as an old acquaintance in England—here's company, farewell.

div.stage: Enter Dullman, Timerous, and Boozer. Hazard sits at a Table and writes.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Here Nell—Well Lieutenant Boozer, what are you for?

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: I am for Cooling Nants, Major:

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Here Nell, a quart of Nants, and some Pipes and smoak.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And do ye hear Nell, bid your Mistriss come in to Joke a little with 〈◊〉 , for adzoors I was damnable drunk last night, and am better at the petticoat than the bottle to day.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Drunk last night, and sick to day, how comes that about Mr. Justice? you use to bear your Brandy well enough.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay your shier-Brandy I'le grant you, but I was Drunk at Coll. Downrights with your high Burgundy Claret.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: A Pox of that Paulter Liquor, your English French wine, I wonder how the Gentlemen do to drink it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay so do I, 'tis for want of a little Virginia Breeding: how much more like a Gentleman 'tis, to drink as we do, brave Edifying Punch and Brandy,—but they say the young Noble-men now and Sparks in England begin to reform, and take it for their mornings Draught, get Drunk by noon, and despise the Lowsey Juce of the Grape.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Come Landlady, come, you are so taken up with Parson Dunce, that your old friends can't Drink a Dram with you,—what no smutty Catch now, no Gibe or Joke to make the Punch go down Merrily, and advance Trading? Nay, they say, Gad forgive ye, you never miss going to Church when Mr. Dunce Preaches—but here's to you▪

sp.speaker:
Flir •…
▪
sp.p: Lords, your Honours are pleas'd to be merry—but my service to your Honour.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Honours, who the Devill have we here? some of the wise Councill at least, I'd sooner took 'em for Hoggerds.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Say what you please of the Doctor, but I'le swear he's a fine Gentleman, he makes the Prettiest Sounets, nay, and Sings 'em himself to the rarest Tunes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay the man will serve for both Soul and Body, for they say he was a Farrier in England, but breaking turn'd Life-guard man, and his Horse dying—he Counterfeited a Deputation from the Bishop, and came over here a Substantiall Orthodox: but come, where stands the Cup?—here, my Service to you Major.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Your Honours are pleas'd—but me-thinks Doctor Dunce is a very Edifying Person, and a Gentleman, and I pretend to know a Gentleman,—For I my self am a Gentlewoman; my Father was a Barronet, but undone in the late Rebellion—and I am fain to keep on Ordinary now, Heaven help me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Good lack, why see how Virtue may be bely'd—we heard your Father was a Taylor, but trusting for old Olivers Funerall, Broke, and so came hither to hide his head,—but my Service to you; what, you are never the worse?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p:
Your Honours knows this is a Scandalous place, for they say
your Honour was but a broken Excise-ma •… , who spent the Kings money to buy your Wife •… ne Petticoats, and at last •… ot worth a Groat, you came over a poor Servant, though now a Justice of Peace, and of the Honourable Council.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Adz zoors if I knew who 'twas said so, I'd sue him for Scandalum Magnatum.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Hang 'em Scoundrells, hang 'em, they live upon Scandal, and we are Scandall-Proof,—They say too, that I was a Tinker and runing the Country, robb'd a Gentlemans House there, was put into Newgate, got a reprieve after Condemnation, and was Transported hither—And that you Boozer was a Common Pick-pocket, and being often flogg'd at the Carts-tale, afterwards turn'd Evidence, and when the times grew Honest was fain to fly.

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Major, if Scandal would have broke our hearts, we had not arriv'd to the Honour of being Pri •… y-Councellors—but come Mrs. Flirt, what never a Song to Entertain us?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Yes, and a Singer too newly come ashore:

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Adz zoors, let's have it then:
sp.stage:
[Enter Girl, who sings, they bear the 〈◊〉
▪

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Here Maid, a Tankard of your Drink;

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Quickly Nell, wait upon the Gentleman;

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Please you Sir to tast of our Liquor—My service to you 〈◊〉 see you are a Stranger and alone, please you to come to our Table?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p:
Come Sir, pray sit down here, these are very Honourable Persons I assure you,—This is Major Dullman, Major of his Excellencies own Regiment, when he Arrives, this Mr. Timorous, Justice a Peace in
〈◊〉
T •… s Capt.
〈◊〉 , all of the Honourable Councill.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: With your leave, Gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: What have you brought over any Cargo Sir, I'le be your Customer.

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: Ay, and cheat him too, I'le warrant him.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I was not bred to Merchandizing Sir, nor do intend to follow the Drudgery of Trading.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Men of Fortune seldom travell hither Sir to see fashions.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why Brother, it may be the Gentleman has a mind to be a Planter, will you hire your self to make a Crop of Tobacco this year?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I was not born to work Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Not work Sir, zoors your betters have workt Sir, I have work •… my self Sir▪ both set and stript Tobacco, for all I am of the Honourable Councill not work quoth a—I suppose Sir you wear your fortune upon your Pack Sir?

sp.speaker: Haz
sp.p: Is ityour Custom here Sir to affront Strangers? I shall expect satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why does any body here owe you any thing?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: No, unless he means to be paid for drinking with us—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: No Sir, I have money to pay for what I drink: here's my Club—my Guinia,
I scorn to be oblig'd to such Scoundrells;

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: Hum—Call Men of Honour Scoundrells;

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Let him alone, let him alone Brother, how should he learn manners, he never was in Virginia before.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: He's some Covent-Garden Bully;

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Or some broken Citizen turn'd Factor,

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Sir you lye, and you're a Rascall,

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Adz zoors he has spill'd all the Brandy.
sp.stage: Tim. runs behind the door, Dull. and Booz. strike Hazard.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I understand no Cudgel Play, but wear a sword to right my self.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Good heavens, what quarelling in my House?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Do the Persons of Quallity in this Country treat strangers thus?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Alas Sir, 'tis a familiar way they have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I'm glad I known it,—Pray Madam can you inform one how I may be furnisht with a Horse and a guide to Madam Sure Loves?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: A most Accomplisht Lady, and my very good friend you shall be Immediately—

div.head: SCENE, II.
div.stage: Enter Wellman, Downright, Dunte, Whimsey, Whiff, and others.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Come Mr. Dunce, tho' you are no Councellour, yet your Council may be good in time of necessity, as now.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: If I may be worthy advice, I do not look upon our danger to be so great from the Indians, as from young Bacon, whom the People have nick nam'd Fright-all.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ay, Ay that same Bacon, I would he were well hang'd, I am afraid that under pretence of killing all the Indians he means to Murder us, Ly with our Wives, and hang up our little Children, and make himself Lord and King.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Brother Whimsey, not so hot, with leave of the Honourable Board, My Wife is of Opinion, that Bacon came seasonably to our Aid, and what he has done was for our defence, the Indians came down upon us, and Ravisht us all, Men, Women, and Children.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p:
If these Grievances were not redres •… we had our reasons for it, it was not that we were insensible Capt. Whiff of what we suffer'd from the Insolence of the Indians: But all knew what we must expect from Bacon if that by Lawfull Authority he had Arriv'd to so great a Command
as Generall, nor would we be huft out of our Commissions.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: 'Tis most certain that Bacon did not demand a Commission out of a design of serving us, but to satisfy his Ambition and his Love, it being no secret that he passionately Admires the Indian Queen, and under the pretext of a War, intends to kill the King her Husband, Establish himself in her heart, and on all occasions have himself a more formidable Enemy, than the Indians are.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I ever foresaw he would prove a Villain.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Nay, and he be thereabout, my Nancy shall have no more to do with him.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: But Gentlemen the People dayly flock to him, so that his Army is too Considerable for us to oppose by any thing but Policy.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: We are sensible Gentlemen that our Fortunes, our Honours, and our Lives are at Stake, and therefore you are call'd together to consult what's to be done in this Grand Affair, till our Governout and Forces arrive from England; The Truce he made with the Indians will be out to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Ay, and then he intends to have another bout with the Indians. Let's have Patience I say till he has thrum'd their Jackets, and then to work with your Politicks as soon as you please.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Colonel Wellman has answer'd that point good Captain Whiff, 'tis the Event of this Battle we ought to dread, and if won or lost will be equally fatall for us, either from the Indians or from Bacon.

sp.speaker: Dunce.
sp.p: With the Permission of the Honourable Board I think I have hit upon an Expedient that may prevent this Battle, your Honours shall write a Letter to Bacon, where you shall acknowledge his Services, invite him kindly home, and offer him a Commission for General—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Just my Nancys Counsell—Doctor Dunce has spoken like a Cherubin, he shall have my voice for General, what say you Brother Whimsey?

sp.speaker: Dunce.
sp.p: I say, he is a Noble fellow, and fit for a General.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: But conceive me right Gentlemen, as soon as he shall have render'd himself, seize him and strike off his Head at the Fort.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Hum! his head—Brother

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Doctor Dunce speaks like a Cherubin:

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Mr Dunce, your Counsell in extremity I confess is not amiss, but I should be loath to deal dishonourably with any man.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: His Crimes deserve death, his life is forfeited by Law, but shall never be taken by my consent by Trechery: If by any Stratagem we could take him a-live, and either send him for England to receive there his Punishment, or keep him Prisoner here till the Governour arrive, I should agree to't, but I question his coming in upon our Invitation.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Leave that to me▪

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Come, I'le warrant him, the Rogue's as stont as Hector, he fears neither Heaven nor Hell.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: He's too Brave and Bold to refuse our summons, and I am for sending him for England and leaving him to the Kings Mercy.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: In that you'l find more difficulty Sir, to take him off here will be more quick and sudden: for the people worship him.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I'le never yield to so ungenerous an expedient. The seizing him I am content in the Extremity wherein we are, to follow. What say you Collonell Downright? shall we send him a Letter now while this two days truce lasts, between him and the Indians?

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I approve i •… .

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And I, and I, and I.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: If your Honours please to make me the Messenger, I'le use some arguments of my own to prevail with him.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You say well Mr. Dunce, and we'l dispatch you presently.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Ah Doctor, if you could but have persuaded Collonell Wellman & Collonel Downright to have hang'd him—
sp.stage: Ex. Wellm. Dow. and all but Whim. Whiff. & Dunce.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Why Brother Whiff you were for making him a Generall but now.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: The Councills of wise States-men Brother Whimsey must change as causes do, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Your Honours are in the right, and whatever those two leading Councellors say, they would be glad if Bacon were dispatcht, but the punctillio of Honour is such a thing.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Honour, a Pox on't, what is that Honour that keeps such a Bustle in the world, yet never did good as I heard of.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Why 'tis a Foolish word only, taken up by great men, but rarely practic'd,—but if you would be great men indeed—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: If we would Doctor, name, name the way.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Why, you command each of you a company—when Bacon comes from the Camp, as I am sure he will, (and full of this silly thing call'd Honour will come unguarded too,) lay some of your men in Ambush along those Ditches by the Sevana about a Mile from the Town, and as he comes by, seize him, and hang him upon the next Tree.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Hum—hang him! a rare Plot.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Hang him—we'l do't, we'l do't Sir, and I doubt not but to be made Generall for the Action—I'le take it all upon my self.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: If you resolve upon this, you must about it instantly—Thus I shall at once serve my Country, & revenge my self on the Rascall for affronting my Dignity once at the Councell-Table, by calling me Farrier

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Do you know Brother what we are to do?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: To do, yes, to hang a Generall, Brother, that's all.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: All, but is it Lawfull to hang any Generall?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Lawfull, yes, that •… is Lawfull to hang any G •… nerall that sights against Law.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: But in what he has done, he has sorv'd the King and our Country, and preserv'd all our Lives and Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: That's all one, Brother, if there be but a Quirk in the Law offended in this Case, tho' he fought like Alexander, and preserv'd the whole world from perdition, yet if he did it against Law, 'tis Lawful to hang him; why what Brother, is it fit that every impudent fellow that pretends to a little Honour, Loyalty & Courage, should serve his King and Country ag •… inst the Law? no, no, Brother, these things are not to b •… suffer'd in a Civill Government by Law Establish'd,—wherefore let's about it—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Here Jesiry, ye D •… unken Dog, set your Coach and Horses up, 'le not go till the Cool of the Evening, I love to ride in Fresco

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Yes after hard drinking— (aside) it shall be done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: how now Boy, is Madam Surelove at home?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Go tell her I am here, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Who are you pray, forsooth?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Why you Son of Baboone don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No Madam, I came over but in the last Ship.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: What from Newgate or Bridewell? from shovi •… g the Fu •… ler, Sirrah, Lifting or •… ing the Cly?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I don't understand this Country-Language for sooth, yet.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
You Rogue, 'tis what we transport from England
•… ost—go ye D •… g, go tell your Lady, the Widow Ranter is come to dine with her—I hope I shall not find that Rogue Dareing here. S •… ling after [Ex. Boy. Mrs. Chrisame: if I 〈◊〉 , by the Lord, 'e Lay him thick, Pox on him why should I love the Dog, unless it be a Judgment upon me.
—My dear I w •… ll how do'st do?—as for you Gentlewoman you are my Rivall, & I am in rancouragai •… st you till you have renounc'd my Dareing.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: All the Interest I have in him Madam, I resign to you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Ay— •… ut your house lying so near the Camp, gives me Mortal sears—but •… thee how thrives thy Amour with honest Friendly?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: As well as a •… Amour can, that is absolutely forbid by a Father on one side, and pursu'd by a good resolution on the other.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Hay Gad, I'le warrant for Friendlys resolution, what, tho' his Fortune be not answerable to yours, we are bound to help one another▪—here Boy—some Pipes and a Bowle of Punch, you know my humour Madam, I must Smoke and Drink in a Morning, or I am Mauki •… h all day.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: But will you drink Punch in a Morning▪

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Punch, 'tis my Mornings draught, my Table-drink, my Treat, my Regalio, my every thing, ah my dear Surelove, if thou woud'st but refresh & Chear thy heart with Punch in a morning, thou wou'dst not look thus Clowdy all the Day.
sp.stage: Enter Pipes and a Great Bowl, she falls to smoaking

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I have reason Madam to be Melancholy, I have receiv'd a Letter from my Husband, who gives t •… e an account that he is worse in England than when he was here, so that I fear I shall see him no more, the Doctors can do no good on him.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: A yery good hearing. I wonder what the Devill thou hast done with him so long? an old fusty weather-beaten Skelleton, as dri'd as Stock-fish, and much of the Hue.—come, come, here's to the next, may he be young, Heaven, I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: You have reason to praise an old man, who dy'd and left you worth fifty thousand Pound.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Ay Gad—and what's better Sweet-heart, dy'd in good time too, and left me young enough to spend this fifty thousand pound in better Company—rest his Soul for that too.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I doubt 'twill be all laid out in Bacons Mad Lieutenant Generall Darling.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Faith I think I could lend it the Rogue on good Security.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What's that, to be bound Body for Body?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Rather that he should love no bodies Body besides my own, but my Fortune is too good to trust the Rogue, my money makes me an Infidell.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: You think they all love you for that:

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: For that, Ay what else? if it were not for that, I might sit still and sigh, and cry out, a Miracle! a Miracle! at sight of a Man within my doors:

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam here's a young Gentleman without would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: With me, sure thou'rt mistaken, is it not Friendly?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No Madam 'tis a Stranger;

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: 'Tis not Dareing that Rogue, is it?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Is he handsome? does he look like a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: He's handsome and seems a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Bring him in then, I hate a conversation without a Fellow,—hah—a good handsome Lad indeed:

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: With me Sir would you speak?

sp.speaker: Haz
sp.p: If you are Madam Surelove:

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: So I am call'd;

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Madam I am newly arriv'd from England, and from your Husband my kinsman bring you this—

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Please you to sit Sir;

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: She's extreamly handsome—

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come Sir will you Smoke a Pipe?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I never do Madam—

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Oh fy upon't you must learn then, we all smoke here, 'tis a part of good breeding,—well, well, what Cargo, what goods have ye? any Poynts, Lace, rich Stuffs, Jewells; if you have I'le be your Chafferer, I live hard by, any body will direct you to the widow Ranters.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I have already heard of you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: What you are like all the young Fellows, the first thing they do when they come to a strange place, is to enquire what Fortunes there are.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Madam I had no such Ambition:

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Gad, then you're a fool, Sir, but come, my service to you; we rich Widdows are the best Commodity this Country affords, I'le tell you that.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Sir, my Husband has recommended you here in a most particular manner, by which I do not only find the esteem he has for you, but the desire he has of gaining you mine, which on a double score I render you, first for his sake, next for those Merits that appear in your self.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Madam, the endeavours of my life shall be to express my Gratitude for this great Bounty;

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam Mr. Friendly's here:

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Bring him in;

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Friendly,—I had a dear Friend of that name, who I hear is in these Parts—Pray Heaven it may be he.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: How now Charles.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Madam your Servant—Hah! should not I know you for my dear friend Hazard.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Or you'rs too blame my Friendly:

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethee what calm brought thee ashore?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Fortune de la gar •… , but prethee ask me no questions in so good Company; where a minute lost from this Conversation is a misfortune not to be retriev'd:

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Do'st like her Rogue—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Like her! have I sight, or sense—Why I adore her.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: My Chrisante, I heard your Father would not be here to day, which made me snatch this opportunity of seeing you.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come, Come, a Pox of this whining Love. It spoyls good company:

sp.speaker: Friend,
sp.p: You know my dear friend, these opportunities comes but serd •… m, and therefore I must make 〈◊〉 of ' •… m▪

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come, come, I'le give you a better opportunity at my House to morrow, we are to eat a Buffilo there, and I'le secure the old Gentleman from coming.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Then I shall see Chrisanto once more before I go:

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Go—Heavens—whether my Friendly?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I have received a Commission to go against the Indians, Bacon being sent for home.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: But will he come when sent for?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If he refuse we are to Endeavour to force him.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I do not think he will be sorc'd, not even by Friendly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And faith it goes against my Conscience to lift my Sword against him, for he is truly brave, and what he has done, a Service to the Country, had it but been by Authority.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What pity 'tis there should be such false Maxims in the World, that Noble Actions how ever great, must be Criminall for want of a Law to Authorise 'em.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis pity that when Laws are faulty they should not be mended or abolish •… .

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Hark'ye Charles, by Heaven if you kill my Dareing I'le Pistol you

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: No, widdow I'le spare him for your sake,

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Oh she is all Divine, and all the Breath she utters serves but to blow my Flame,

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam dinner's on the Table——

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Please you Sir, to walk in—come Mr. Friendly.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Prethee good wench bring in the Punch-Bowle:

div.head: SCENE I. A Pavillion.
div.stage: Discovers the Indian King and Queen sitting in State, with Guards of Indians, Men and Women attending: to them Bacon richly dress'd, attended by Daring, Fearless, and other Officers, he bows to the King and Queen, who rise to receive him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I Am sorry Sir, we meet upon these terms, we who so often have embrac'd as friends.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: How charming is the Queen? [aside.] War, Sir, is not my bus'ness, nor my pleasure: Nor was I bred in Arms; My Country's good has forc'd me to assume a Soldiers life: And 'tis with much regret that I Employ the sirst effects of it against my Friends; Yet whilst I may—Whilst this Cessation lasts, I beg we may exchange those Friendships, Sir, we have so often paid in happier Peace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: For your part, Sir, you've been so Noble, that I repent the fatall difference that makes us meet in Arms. Yet tho' I'm young I'm sensible of Injuries; And oft have heard my Grandsire say—That we were Monarchs once of all this spacious World; Till you an unknown People landing here, Distress'd and ruin'd by destructive storms, Abusing all our Charitable Hospitality, Usurp'd our Right, and made your friends your slaves.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
I will not justify the Ingratitude of my fore-fathers, but finding here my Inheritance, I am resolv'd still to maintain it so, And by my sword
which first cut out my Portion, Defend each inch of Land with my last drop of Bloud.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Ev'n his threats have charms that please the heart:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Come Sir, let this ungratefull Theme alone, which is better disputed in the Field.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Is it impossible there might be wrought an understanding betwixt my Lord and you? 'Twas to that end I first desired this truce, My self proposing to be Mediator, To which my Lord Cavarnio shall agree, Could you but Condescend-—I know you're Noble: And I have heard you say our tender Sex could never plead in vain.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Alas! I dare not trust your pleading Madam? A few soft words from such a Charming mouth would make me lay the Conqueror at your feet as a Sacrifice for all the ills he has done you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How strangely am I pleas'd to hear him talk

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sir will you take your seat?
sp.stage: [He leads the Queen to a seat, they sit and talk.]

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Curse on his sports that interrupted me, My very soul was hovering at my Lip, ready to have discover'd all its secrets. But oh! I dread to tell her of my pain, And when I wou'd, an Awfull trembling seizes me, And she can only 〈◊〉 my dying eyes, read all the Sentiments of my Captive heart.

div.stage:
Enter Indians that dance Anticks; After the Dance the King seems in discourse with Bacon, the Queen
〈◊〉 and comes forth.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: The more I gaze upon this English Stranger, the more Confusion struggles in my Soul, Oft I have heard of Love, and oft this Gallant Man (When Peace had made him pay his idle Visits) 〈◊〉 told a thousand tales of dying Maids. And ever when he spoke, my panting heart, with a Prophetick fear in sighs reply'd, I shall fall such a Victim to his Eyes.

sp.speaker: Indian.
sp.p: Sir here's a Messenger from the English Council
Desires admittance to the General.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: With your Permission Sir, he may advance.

div.stage: Re-enter Indian with Dance. A Letter.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: All health and Happyness attend your honour, This from the Honourable Council:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I'le leave you till you have dispatch'd the M •… ger, and then expect your precense in the Royal Tent.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 , read the Letter

sp.speaker: Daring.
sp.p:
SIR, the necessity of what you 〈◊〉
〈◊〉 makes it pardona •… , and we could wish we had done the Country, and our selves so much Justice 〈◊〉 to have given you that Commission you desired—We now finde it reason •… ble 〈◊〉 raise 〈◊〉 forces, to appose these Insolences, which possible yours may
be 〈◊〉 weak to accomplish, to which end the Council is ordered to meet this Evening, and destring you will come and take your place there, and be pleas'd to accept from us a Commission to Command in Chief in this War—Therefore send those Soldiers under your Command to their respective houses, and hast, Sir, to your affectionate Friends—

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Sir, I fear the hearts and Pen did not agree when this was writ

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: A plague upon their shallow Politicks! Do they think to play the old game twice with us?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Away, you wrong the Council, who of themselves are Honourable Gentlemen, but the base Coward fear of some of them, puts the rest on tricks that suit not with their nature.

sp.speaker: Dunce.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis For noble ends you're sent for, and for your safety I'le engage my life.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: By Heaven and so you shall—and pay it too with all the rest of your wise-headed Council.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Your zeal is too Officious now: I see no Treachery, and can fear no danger.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Treachery! now Heavens forbid, are we not Christians Sir, All Friends and Countrymen! believe me Sir, 'tis Honour calls you to increase your fame, and he who would dissuade you is your Enemy.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Go Cant, Sir to the Rabble—for us—we know you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You wrong me when you but suspect for me, let him that acts dishonourably fear. My Innocence, and my good sword's my guard.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: If you resolve to go, we will attend you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: What go like an Invader? No Daring, the Invitation's friendly, and as a friend, attended only by my menial Servants, I'le wait upon the Council, that they may see that when I could Command it I came an humble Suppliant for their favour—You may return, and tell 'em I'le attend.

sp.speaker: Dunce.
sp.p: I kiss your Honour's hand▪—

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: 'Sdeath will you trust the saithless Council Sir, who have so long h •… ld you in hand with promises, That curse of States-men, that unlucky vice that renders even Nobility despis'd.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Perhaps the Council thought me too aspiring, and would not add Wings to my Ambitious flight.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: A pox of their considering caps, and now they find that you can •… ar alone, they send for you to knip your spreading wings.
Now by my soul you shall not go alone.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Forbear, lest I suspect you for a mutineer; I am resolv'd to go.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: What, and send your Army home? a pretty fetch:

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: By Heaven we'le not disband—not till we see how fairly you are dealt with: if you have a Commission to be General, here we are ready to receive new orders: If no—We'l ring 'em such a Thundring Peal shall beat the Town about their Treacherous Ears.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
I do Command you not to stir a man, Till you're inform'd how I
am treated by 'em:—leave me all—
sp.stage: [Exeunt Officers. While Bacon reads the Letter again, To him the Indian Queen, with Women waiting.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Now while my Lord's asleep in his Pavi •… ion I'le try my power with the General, for an Accomodation of a Peace: the very dreams of war fright my soft slumbers that us'd to be employ'd in kinder Bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Ha!—The Queen—What happyness is this presents it self which all my Industry could never gain?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: Prest with the great Extreams of Joy and Fear I trembling stand, unable to approach her:

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I hope you will not think it fear in me, tho' tim'rous as a Dove, by nature fram'd: Nor that my Lord, whose youth's unskill'd in War can either doubt his Courage, or his forces, t •… makes me seek a Reconcilation on any honourable terms of Peace.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Ah Madam! if you knew how absolutely you command my Fate I fear but little honour wonld be left me, since what so e're you ask me I should grant.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Indeed I would not ask your Honour, Sir, That renders you too Brave in my esteem. Nor can I think that you would part with that. No not to save your Life.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I would do more to serve your least Commands than part with triviall Life.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Bless me! Sir, how came I by such a Power?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: The Gods, and Nature gave it you in your Creation, form'd with all the Charms that ever grac'd your Sex.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I'st possible? am I so Beautifull?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: As Heaven, or Angels there:

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Supposing this, how can my Beauty make you so obliging?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Beauty has still a power over great Souls, And from the moment I beheld your eyes, my stubborn heart melted to compliance, and from a nature rough and turbulent, grew Soft and Gentle as the God of Love.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: The God of Love! what is the God of Love?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: 'Tis a resistless Fire, that's kinddl'd thus— takes her by the hand and gazes on her. at every gaze we take from fine Eyes, from such Bashfull Looks, and such soft touches—it makes us sigh—and pant as I do now, and stops the Breath when e're we speak of Pain.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Alas, for me if this should be Love!

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: It makes us tremble, when we touch the fair one, And all the bloud runs shiv'ring thro' the veins, The heart's surrounded with a feeble Languishment, The eyes are dying, and the Cheeks are pale, The tongue is faltring, and the body sainting.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Then I'm undone, and all I feel is Love,

If Love be Catching Sir, by looks and touches, Let us at distance parley—or
rather let me fly, For within veiw, is too near—

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Ah! she retires—displeas'd I fear with my presumptious Love,—Oh pardon, fairest creature:

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I'le talk no more, our words exchange our Souls, and every look •… ades all my blooming honour, like Sun beams, on unguarded Roses—take all our Kingdoms—make our People Slaves, and let me fall beneath your Conquering Sword. But never let me hear you talk again or gaze upon your Eyes—

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: She Loves! by Heaven she Loves! And has not art enough to hide her Flame. tho' she have Cruel honour to suppress it. However I'le pursue her to the Banquet.

div.head: SCENE II. The Widdow Ranters-Hall.
div.stage: Enter Sure-Love fan'd by two Negro's, followed by Hazard.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: This Madam Ranter is so prodigious a Treater—oh! I hate a room that smells of a great Dinner, and what's worse a desert of Punch and Tobacco—what! are you taking leave so soon Cousin?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Yes Madam, but 'tis not fit I should let you know with what regret I go,—but business will be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Some Letters to dispatch to English Ladies you have left behind—come Cousin Confess:

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I own I much admire the English Beauties, but never yet have put their Fetters on—

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Never in Love—oh then you have pleasure to Come.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Rather a Pain when there's no hope atrends it,

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Oh such diseases quickly cure themselves,

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I do not wish to find it so; For even in Pain I find a pleasure too.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: You are infected then, and came abroad for cure.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Rather to receive my wounds Madam;

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Already Sir.—who e're sne be, she made good hast to Conquer, we have few here, boast that Dexterity.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: What think you of Chrisante, Madam?

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: I must confess your Love & your Dispair are there plac •… d right, of which I am not fond of being made a Consident, since I'm assur'd she can Love none but Friendly.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Let her Love on, as long as life shall last, let Friendly take her, and the Universe, so I had my next wish,—
Madam it is your self that I adore,—I should not be so vain to tell you this, bu •… that I know you've found the secret out already from my sighs.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Forbear Sir, and know me for your kinsmans wife, & no more:

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p:
Be Scornfull as you please, rail at my passion, and refuse to hear
it; yet I'le Love on, and hope in spight of you, my Flame shall be so constant and Submissive, it shall compell your heart to some return.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: You're very Confident of your power I perceive, but if you chance to finde your self mistaken, say your opinion and your affectation were misapply'd, and not that I was Cruell,

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Whate're denyalls dwell upon your Tongue, your eyes assure me that your heart is tender,

div.stage: Enter the Bag-Piper, Playing before a great Boule of Punch, carryed between two Negro's, a Highlandler Dancing after it, the Widdow Ranter led by Timerous, Chrisante by Dullman; Mrs. Flirt and Friendly all dancing after it; they place it on the Table.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: This is like the Noble Widdow all over I'faith,

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, the widdows Health in a full Ladle, Major,—but a Pox on't what made that young Fellow here, that affronted us yesterday Major?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Some damn'd Sharper that wou'd lay his Knife aboard your Widdow Cornet.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Zoors if I thought so, I'd Arrest him for Salt and Battery, Lay him in Prison for a Swinging fine and take no Baile.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Nay, had it not been before my Mrs here, Mrs Chrisante, I had swing'd him for his yesterdays affront,—ah my sweet Mistris Chrisante—if you did but know what a power you have over me—

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Oh you're a great Courtier Major:

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Would I were any thing for your sake Madam.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Thou art any thing, but what thou shouldst be, prethee Major leave off being an old Buffoon, that is a Lover turn'd to ridicule by Age, consider thy self a Meer rouling Tun of Nants,—a walking Chimney, ever Smoaking with Nasty Mundungus,—and then thou hast a Countenance like an old worm-eaten Cheese,

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Well widdow, you will Joake, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gad', Zoors She's pure Company, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Duoe.
sp.p: No matter for my Countenance—Coll. Downright likes my Estate and is resolv'd to have it a Match.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Dear Widdow, take off your Damn'd Major, for if he speak another word to Chrisante, I shall be put past all my patience, and fall foul upon him.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: S'life not for the world—Major I bar Love-making within my Territories, 'tis inconsistent with the Punch-Bowle, if you'l drink, do, if not be gone:

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay Gad's Zooks if you enter me at the Punch-Boule, you enter me in Politicks—well 'tis the best Drink in Christendom for a Statesman,

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Come, now you shall see what my high Land-Vallet can do—

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: So—I see let the world go which way it will, widdow, you are resolv'd for Mirth,—but come—to the conversation of the times.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: The times, why what a Devill ailes the times, I see nothing in the times but a company of Coxcombs that fear without a Cause.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: But if these fears were laid and Bacon were hang'd, I look upon Virginia to be the happiest part of the world, gads Zoors,—why there's England—'tis nothing to't—I was in England about 6. years ago, & was shew'd the Court of Aldermen, some were nodding, some saying nothing, and others very little to purpose, but how could it be otherwise, for they had neither Bowle of Punch, Bottles of wine or Tobacco before 'em to put Life & Soul into 'em as we have here: then for the young Gentlemen—Their farthest Travels is to France or Italy, they never come hither.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: The more's the Pitty by my troth,

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Where they learn to Swear Mor-blew, Mor-Dee:

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And tell you how much bigger the Louvre is then White-Hall; buy a sute A-la-mode, get a swinging Cap of some French Marquis, spend all their money and return just as they went.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: For the old fellows, their bus'ness is Usury, Extortion, and undermining young Heirs.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Then for young Merchants, their Exchange the is Tavern, their Ware-house the Play-house, and their Bills of Exchange Billet-Deaxs, where to sup with their wenches at the other end of the Town,—now Judge you what a Condition poor England is in: for my part I look upon't as a lost Nation gads zoors.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I have consider'd it, and have found a way to save all yet:

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: As how I pray,

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: As thus, we have men here of great Experience and Ability—now I would have as many sent into England as would supply all places, and Offices, both Civill and Military, de see, their young Gentry should all Travell hither for breeding, and to learn the misteries of State.

sp.speaker: Frien.
sp.p: As for the old Covetous Fellows, I would have the Tradesmen get in their debts, break and turn Troupers.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And they'd be soon weary of Extortion gadz zoors;

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Then for the young Merchants, there should be a Law made, none should go beyond Ludgate;

sp.speaker: Frie.
sp.p: You have sound out the only way to preserve that great Kingdom,

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well, Gad zoors 'tis a fine thing to be a good Statesman,

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Ay Cornet, which you had never been had you staid in old England.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Why Sir we were somebody in England,

sp.speaker: Frie.
sp.p: So I heard Major,

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p:
You heard Sir, what have you heard, he's a kid-Naper that says
he heard any thing of me—and so my service to you—I'le sue you Sir for spoiling my Marriage here, by your Scandalls with Mrs. Chrisante, but that shan't do Sir, I'le marry her for all that, & he's a Rascal that denies it.

sp.speaker: Frie.
sp.p: S'death you Lye Sir—I do.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gad zoors Sir Lye to a Privy-Councellour, a Major of Horse, Brother, this is an affront to our Dignities, draw and I'le side with you.
sp.stage: [they both draw on Friendly, the Ladies run off.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: If I disdain to draw, 'tis not that I fear your base and Cowardly force, but for the respect I bear you as Magistrates, and so I leave you—

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: An Arrant Coward Gad zoors.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: A meer paultroon, and I scorn to drink in's Company.

div.head: SCENE III. A Sevana, or large Heath.
div.stage: Enter Whimsey, Whiff, and Boozer, with some Soldiers, Arm'd.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Stand—stand—and hear the word of Command—do ye see you Cops, and that Ditch that runs along Major Dullmans Plantation.

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Place your Men there, and lye Flat on your Bellies, and when Bacon comes (if alone) seize him dy' see:

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Observe the Command now, (if alone) for we are not for bloud- •… ned.

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: I'le warrant you for our Parts.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Now we have Ambusht our men, let's light our Pipes and sit down and take an Encouraging dram of the Bottle.
sp.stage: [pulls out a bottle of brandy out of his Pocket—they sit.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Thou art a Knave and hast Emptyed half the Bottle in thy Leathern Pockets, but come here's young Fright-all's health.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: What, wilt drink a mans health thou'rt going to hang?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: 'Tis all one for that, we'le drink his health first, and hang him afterwards, and thou shalt pledge me de see, and tho' 'twere under the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Thou'rt a Traytor for saying so, and I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Nay, since we are come out like Loving Brothers to hang the Generall, let's not fall out among our selves, and so here's to you [drinks tho' I have no great Maw to this business:

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Prethee Brother Whiff, do not be so Villanous a Coward, for I hate a Coward.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Nay 'tis not that—But my Whiff, my Nancy dreamt to night she saw me hang'd.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p:
'Twas a Cowardly Dream, think no more on't, but as dreams
are Expounded by Contraries, thou shalt hang the Generall.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Ay—but he was my friend, and I owe him at this time a hundréd Pounds of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Nay, then I m sure thoud'st hang him if he were thy brother.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: But hark—I think I hear the Neighing of horses, where shall we hide our selves, for if we stay here, we shall be Mawl'd damnably.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Let the Groom lead the Horses o're the Sevana we'le walk it on Foot, 'tis not a quarter of a Mile to the Town; & here the Air is cool.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: The Breazes about this time of the day begin to take Wing and fan refreshment to the Trees and Flowers.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: And at these hours how fragrant are the Groves:

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: The Country's well, were but the People so,

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: But come let's on—

sp.speaker: Whi •… .
sp.p: There Boys—
sp.stage: [The Soldiers come forth and fall on Bacon.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Hah! Ambush—
sp.stage: Draws, Fearless and Foot •… n draw, the Soldiers after a while fighting take Bac. & Fear. they having laid 3 or 4 Dead.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: So, so, he's taken
Now we may venture out.

sp.speaker: Whi •… .
sp.p: But are you sure he's taken?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Sure can't you believe your Eyes, come forth, I hate a Coward—Oh Sir, have we caught your Mightiness?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Are you the Authors of this Valliant Act? None but such Villainous Cowards dar'st have attempted it▪

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Stop his railing tongue.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: No, no, let him rail, let him rail now his hands are tyed, ha, ha, Why good Generall Fright-all, what was no body able d'ye think to tame the Roaring Lyon?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You'le be hang'd for this?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Come, come, away with him to the next Tree.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: What mean you Villains?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Only to hang your Honour a little, that's all. We'le teach you Sir, to serve your Country against Law.
sp.stage: [As they go off, Enter Daring with Soldiers.]

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Hah—My General betray'd—this I suspected.
sp.stage: His Men come in, they fall on, Release Bacon and Fearless and his Man, who get Swords. Whim's Party put Whim and Whiff before 'em striking 'em as they Endeavour to run on this side or that, and forcing 'em to bear-up, th •… y are taken after some Fighting.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Did not the General tell you Rogues, you'd be all hang'd?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Oh Nancy, Nancy, how Prophetick are thy Dreams?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Come let's on—

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: S'death what mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: As I design'd—to present my self to the Council:

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: By Heavens we'le follow then to save you from their Treachery 'twas this that has befallen you that I fear'd, which made me at a distance follow you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Follow me still, but still at such a distance as your Aids may be assisting on all occasion—Fearless go back and bring your Regiment down, and Daring let your Sergeant with his Party Guard these Villains to the Council.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: A Pox on your Worships Plot;

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: A Pox on your forwardness to come out of the hedge.

div.head: SCENE IV. The Council-Table.
div.stage: Enter Coll. Wellman, Coll. Downright, Dullman, Timerouse, and about 7 or 8 more Seat themselves.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You heard Mr. Dunce's opinion Gentlemen, concerning Bacon's coming upon our Invitation. He believes he will come, but I rather think, tho' he be himself undaunted, yet the persuasions of his two Lieutenant-Generalls, Daring and Fearless may prevent him,—Colonel, have you order'd our Men to be in Arms?

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I have, and they'l attend further order on the Sevana:

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: May it please your Honours, Bacon is on his way, he comes unattended by any but his Footmen, and Coll. Fearless.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Who is this Fellow?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: A spy I sent to watch Bacon's Motions.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: But there is a Company of Soldiers in Ambush on this side of the Sevana to seize him as he passes by.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: That's by no order of the Council.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No, no, no order;

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Nay, 'twere a good design if true,

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gad zoors would I had thought on't for my Troup,

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I am for no unfair dealing in any Extremity.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: An't please your Honours, the saddest news—An Ambush being laid for Bacon, they rusht out upon him, on the Sevana, and after some fighting took him and Fearless—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Is this your sad News—zoors would I had had a hand in't.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p:
When on a sudden, Daring and his Party fell in upon us, turn'd the tide—kill'd our men and took Capt. Whimsey, and Capt. Whiff Pris'ners,
the rest run away, but Bacon fought like a fury.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A bloudy Fellow;

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Whim. and Whiff? they deserve death for Acting without order

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'm of the Colonels opinion, they deserve to hang for't.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Why Brother, I thought you had wisht the Plot had been yours but now?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, but the Case is alter'd since that, good Brother,

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Now he's Exasperared past all hopes of a Reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: You must make use of the Statesman's refuge, wise dissimulation.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: For all this Sir, he will not believe but that you mean Honourably, and no persuasions could hinder him from Coming, so he has dismist all his Soldiers, and is Entring the Town on foot,

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What pitty 'tis a brave Man should be Guilty of an ill Action.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: But the noise of his danger has so won the hearts of the Mobile, that they encrease his Train as he goes, & follow him in the Town like a Victor.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Go wait his coming [Ex. Brag. he grows too popular, and must be humbled,

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I was ever of your mind Colonel.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Ay right or Wrong—but what's your Counsell now?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: E'en as it us'd to be, I leave it to wiser heads.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Bacon Sir is Entring.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gad zoors wou'd I were safe in Bed,

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Colonel keep in your heat and treat Calmly with him,

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I rather wish you wou'd all follow me, I'd meet him at the head of all his noisy Rabble, and seize him from the rout.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: What Men of Authority dispute with Rake-Hells? 'tis below us Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: To Stake our Lives and Fortunes against their nothing.
sp.stage: Enter Bacon, after him the Rabble with Staves and Clubs bringing in Whim. & Whiff. bound.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What means this Insolence—What Mr. Bacon do you come in Arms?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I'de need Sir come in Arms, when men that should be Honourable can have so poor designs to take my life.

sp.speaker: Well,
sp.p: Thrust out his following Rabble.

sp.speaker: First Rab.
sp.p: We'le not Stirr till we have the General safe back again.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Let not your Loves be too Officious—but retire—

sp.speaker: 1st. Rab.
sp.p: At your Command we vanish—

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I hope you'l pardon me, if in my own defence I seiz'd on these two Murderers.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: You did well Sir, 'twas by no Order they Acted,—stand forth and here your Sentence—in time of war we need no Formall Tryalls to hang Knaves that Act without order.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Oh Mercy Mercy Collonell—'twas Parson Dunce's Plot.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Issue out a warrant to Seize Dunce Immediately—you shall he carry'd—to the Fort to Pray—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Oh Good your Honour I never Pray'd in all my Life,

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: From thence Drawn upon a Sledg to the Place of •… xecution,—where you shall hang till you are dead—and then be •… ut down and—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Oh hold—hold—we shall never be able to endure •… lf this:

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I think th'offence needs not so great Punishment, their Crime Sir is but equall to your own, acting without Commission.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: 'Tis very well Explain'd Sir,—had I been Murder'd by Commission then, the Deed had been approv'd, and now perhaps, I am beholding to the Rable for my Life:—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: A fine pretence to hide a Popular fault, but for this once we Pardon them and you,

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Pardon, for what? by Heaven I Scorn your Pardon, I've not offended Honour nor Religion:

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You have offended both in taking Arms,

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Shou'd I stand by and see my Country ruin'd, my King dishonour'd, and his Subjects Murder'd hear the sad Crys of widdows and of Orphans, You heard it Lowd, but gave no pitying care to't▪ And till the war and Massacre was brought to my own door, my Flocks, and Heards surpriz'd, I bore it all with Patience, Is it unlawfull to defend my self against a Thief that breaks into my doors?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And call you this defending of your self?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I call it doing of my self that right, which upon Just demand the Councill did refuse me, If my Ambition as you're pleas'd to call it, made me demand too Much, I left my self to you:

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Perhaps we thought it did,

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Sir you affront my Birth,—I am a Gentleman, And yet my thoughts were humble—I wou'd have fought under the meanest of your Parasites—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: There's a Bob for us Brother;

sp.speaker: Bac
sp.p: But still you put me off with promises—And when compell'd to stir in my defence I call'd none to my aid, and those that came, 'twas their own wrongs that urg'd 'em:

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: 'Tis fear'd Sir, under this pretence you aim at Government:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I scorn to answer to so base an accusation, the height of my Ambition is, to be an honest Subject.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: An honest Rebell, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You know you wrong me, and 'tis basely urg'd—but this is trifling—here are my Commissions.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: —To be General of the Forces against the Indians, and Blank Commissions for his Friends.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Tear them in peices—are we to be imposed upon? De ye come in Hostile manner to compel us?

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Be not to rough Sir, let us argue with him—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I am resolved I will not.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Then we are all Dead Men, Gudzoors! he will not give us time to say our Prayers.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: We every day expect fresh Force from England, till then, we of our selves shall be sufficient to make Defence, against a sturdy Traytor.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Traytor, 'Sdeath Traytor—I defie ye, but that my Honour's yet above my Anger; I'd make you answer me that Traytor dearly.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hah—am I threatned—Guards secure the Rebel.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Is this your Honourable Invitation? Go—Triumph in your short Liv'd Victory, the next turn shall be mine.
sp.stage: A noise of Fighting—Enter Bacon, Wellman, his Guards Beat back by the Rabble, Bacon snatches a Sword from one, and keeps back the Rabble, Tim. gets under the Table.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: What means this Insolence!

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: We'l have our General, and knock that fellows brains out, and hang up Collonel Wellman.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay ay, Hang up Wlelman.
sp.stage: The Rabble seize Wellman, and Dullman, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Hold, hold Gentleman, I was always for the General.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Let's Barbicu this Fat Rogue.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Begone, and know your dista •… ce to theCouncel.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I'd rather perish by the meanest hand, than owe my safety poorly thus to Bacon

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: If you persist still in that mind I'le leave you, and Conquering, make you happy 'gainst your will.
sp.stage: [Ex. Bacon and Rabble, Hollowing a Pacon, a Bacon.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Oh Villanous Cowards, who will trust his Honour with Sycophants so base? Let us to Arms—by Heaven I will not give my Body rest, till I've Chastiz'd the boldness of this Rebel.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Well. Down. and the rest all but Dullman, Tim. Peeps from underthe Table.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What is the Roystering Hector gone Brother?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and the Devil go with him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Was there ever such a Bull of Bash •… n? Why what if he should come down upon us and kill us all for Traytors?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I rather think the Councel will Hang us all for Cowards—ah—oh—a Drum—a Drum—oh—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: This is the misery of being Great,
We're Sacrific'd to every turn of State.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: The Country Court, a great Table, with Papers, a Clerk writing. Enter a great many people of all sorts, then Friendly, after him Dullman.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: HOw now Major; what, they say Bacon scar'd you all out of the Council yesterday: What say the People?

sp.speaker: Dull.
