sp.p: Say? they Curse us all, and Drink young Frightall's Health, and swear they'll fight thro Fire and Brimstone for him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And to morrow will hallow him to the Gallows, if it were his chance to come there.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely: Why I am forc'd to be guarded to the Court now, the Rabble swore they would De Wit me, but I shall hamper some of 'em. Wou'd the Governour were here to bear the brunt on't, for they call us the Evil Counsellors.
Here's the young Rogue that drew upon us too, we have Rods in piss for him ifaith.
sp.stage: 'Enter Timerous with Bayliffs, whispers to Dullman, after which to the Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gadzoors that's he, do your Office.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.p: We arrest you Sir, in the Kings name, at the suit of the Honourable Justice Timerous.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Justice Timerous, who the Devil's he?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I am the man Sir, de see, for want of a better; you shall repent Gud •… zoors your putting of tricks upon persons of my Rank and Quality.
sp.stage: After he has spoke he runs back as afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Your Rank and Quality!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay Sir, my Rank and Quality; first I am one of the Honourable Council, next a Justice of Peace in Quorum, Cornet of a Troop of Horse de see, and Church-warden.

sp.speaker: Frie.
sp.p: From whence proceeds this Mr. Justice, you said nothing of this at Madam Ranters Yesterday; you saw him there, then you were good Friends?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, however I have carried my Body swimmingly before my Mistress, de see, I had rancour in my Heart, Gads zoors.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: VVhy, this Gentleman's a stranger, and but lately come a shore.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p:
At my first Landing I was in company with this Fellow and two
or three of his cruel Brethren, where I was affronted by them, some words past and I drew—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay ay Sir, you shall pay for't,—why—what Sir, cannot a Civil Magistrate affront a Man, but he must be drawn upon presently?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well Sir, the Gentleman shall answer your Sute, and I hope you'l take my Bail for him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis enough—I know you to be a Civil Person.
sp.stage: Timerous and Dullman take their Places, on a long Bench placed behind the Table, to them Whimsey an Whiff, they seat themselves, then Boozer and two or three more; who seat themselves: Then enter two bearing a Bowl of Punch, and a great Ladle or two in it; the rest of the Stage being filled with People.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Brothers it has been often mov'd at the Bench, that a new Punch Bowl shou'd be provided, and one of a larger Circumference, when the Bench sits late about weighty affairs, oftentimes the Bowl is emptyed before we end.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: A good Motion, Clark set it down.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: Mr. Justice Boozer the Council has ordered you a writ of Ease, and dismiss your Worship from the Bench.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Me from the Bench, for what?

sp.speaker: Whim▪
sp.p: The Complaint is Brother Boozer, for Drinking too much Punch in the time of hearing Tryals.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: And that you can neither write nor read, nor say the Lords Prayer.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That your Warrants are like a Brewers Tally a Notch on a Stick; if a special Warrant, then a Couple. Gods Zoors, when his Excellency comes he will have no such Justices.

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: Why Brother, tho I can't read my self; I have had Dol •… ns Country-Justice read over to me two or three times, and understand the Law; this is your Malice Brother Whiff, because my Wife does not come to your Ware-House to buy her Commodities,—but no matter, to show I have no Malice in my heart, I drink your Health—I care not this, I can turn Lawyer and plead at the Board.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Mr. Clark, come, to the Tryals on the Docket.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The first is between his Worship Justice Whiff, and one Grubb.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Ay, that Grubb's a Common Disturber, Brother your Cause, is a good Cause if well manag'd, here's to't.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: I thank you Brother Dullman,—read my Petition.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The Petition of Captain Thomas Whiff Sheweth, whereas Gilbert. Grubb, calls his Worships Wife Ann Grabb Whore, and said he would prove it; your Petitioner desires the Worshipful Bench to take it into Consideration, and your Petitioner shall pray, &c.—Here's two witnesses have made Affidavit Vive voce, an't like your Worships.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Call Grubb.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Gilbert Grubb, come into the Court.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Well, what can you say for your self Mr. Grub.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Why an't like your Worship, my wife invited some Neighbours wives to drink a Cagg of Syder, now your worships wife Madam Whiff being there fuddl'd, would have thrust me out of doors, and bid me go to my old Whore Madam Whimscy, meaning your Worships wife.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Hah! My wife called Whore, she's a Jude, & I'le arrest her Husband here—in an Action of debts.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gads zoures she's no better than she should be I'le warrant her,

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Look ye Brother Whimsey, be patient, you know the Humour of my Nancy when she's drunk, but when she's sober, she's a civil Person, and shall ask your pardon.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Let this be done and I am satisfied. And so here's to you

sp.speaker: Dull:
sp.p: Go on to the Tryal.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: I being very angry said indeed, I would prove her a greater Whore than Madam Whimsey.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: An't like your Whrships, he confesses the words in open Court.

sp.speaker: Grub.
sp.p: Why, an't like your Worships, she has had two Bastards I'le prove it.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Sirrah, Sirrah, that was when she was a Maid, not since I married her, my marrying her made her Honest.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Let there be an order of Court to Sue him, for Scandalum Magnatum.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Mr. Clark, let my Cause come next.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: The Defendant's ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Brothers of the Bench take notice, that this Hector here coming into Mrs. Flirts Ordinary where I was, with my Brother Dullman and Lieutenant Boozer; we gave him good Councel to fall to Work, now my Gentleman here was affronted at this Forsooth, and makes no more to do but calls us Scoundrels, and drew his Sword on us, and had not I defended my self by running away, he had Murdered me, and Assassinated my two Brothers.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: What witness have you Brother?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Here's Mrs. Flirt and her Maid Nell,—besides we may be witness for one another I hope; our words may taken.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: Mrs. Flirt and Nell are Sworn.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: By the Oaths that you have taken, speak nothing but the Truth.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p:
An't please your Worships, your Honours came to my House, where you found this Young Gentleman; and your Honours invited him to Drink with your Honours: Where after some opprobrious words given
him, Justice Dullman, and Justice Boozer struck him over the head; and after that indeed the Gentleman drew.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Mark that Brother he drew.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: If I did, it was se defendendo.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Do you hear that Brothers, he did in defiance.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Sir, you ought not to sit Judge and Accuser too.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: The Gentlemans i'th' right Brother, you cannot do it according to Law.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gads Zoors, what new tricks, new querks?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Gentlemen take notice, he swears in Court.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gads Zoors what's that to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: This is the second time of his swearing.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: What do you think we are Deaf Sir? Come, come proceed.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I desire he may be bound to his Good behaviour, Fin'd and deliver up his Sword, what say you Brot her?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: He's asleep, drink to him and waken him,—you have have mist the Cause by sleeping Brother.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Justice may nod, but never sleeps Brother—you were at—Deliver his Sword—a good Motion, let it be done.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: No Gentlemen, I wear a Sword to right my self.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That's fine i'faith, Gads Zoors, I have worn a Sword this Duzen year and never cou'd right my self.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Ay, 'twou'd be a fine World if Men shou'd wear Swords to right themselves, he that's bound to the Peace shall wear no Sword.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I say he that's bound to the Peace ought to wear no Peruke, they may change 'em for black or white, and then who can know them.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I hope Gentlemen I may be allowed to speak for my self.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Ay, what can you say for your self, did you not draw your Sword Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis sufficient he confesses the Fact, and we'l hear no more.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: You will not hear the Provocation given.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: 'Tis enough Sir, you drew—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, 'tis enough he drew—let him be Fin'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: The Gentleman shou'd be heard, he's a Kinsman too, to Collonel John Surelove.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hum—Collonel Sureloves Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Is he so, nay, then all the reason in the VVorld he should be heard, Brothers.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Come, come Cornet, you shall be Friends with the Gentleman, this was some Drunken bout I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—so it was Gads Zoors.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Come drink to the Gentleman, and put it up.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, my Service to you, I am heartily sorry for what's past, but it was in my Drink.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: You hear his acknowledgements Sir, and when he is sober he never quarrels, come Sir sit down, my Service to you.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I beg your Excuse Gentlemen—I have earnest business.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Let us adjourn the Court, and prepare to meet the Regiments on the Sevana.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Is this the best Court of Judicature your Country affords?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: To give it its due it is not. But how does thy Armour thrive?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: As well as I can wish, in so short a time.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I see she regards thee with kind Eyes, Sighs and Blushes.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Yes, and tells me I am so like a Brother she had—to Excuse her kind concern,—then blush so prettily, that Gad I cou'd not forbear making a discovery of my Heart.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Have a care of that, come upon her by slow degrees, for I know she's Vertuous;—but come let's to the Sevana, where I'le present you to the two Collonels, Wellman and Downright, the Men that manage all till the Carrival of the Governour.

div.head: SCENE II. The Sevana or Heath: Enter Wellman, Downright, Boozer, and Officers.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Have you dispatcht the Scouts, to watch the Motions of the Enemies? I know that Bacon's Violent and Haughty, and will resent our vain attempts upon him; therefore we must be speedy in prevention.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: What forces have you raised since our last order.

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: Here's a list of em, they came but slowly in, till we promised every one a Bottle of Brandy.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: We have brought Mr. Dunce here, as your Honour commanded us after strict search we found him this morning in Bed with Madam Flirt.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: No matter he'l exclaim no less against the vices of the Flesh, the next Sunday.

sp.speaker: Dunc.
sp.p: I hope Sir, you will not credit the Malice of my Enemies.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: No more, you are free, and what you councell'd about the Ambush was both prudent and seasonable, and perhaps I now wish it had taken effect.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I have brought an English Gentleman to kiss your hands, Sir, and offer you his service, he is young and brave, and Kinsman to Col. Surelove.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sir, you are welcom and to let you see you are so, we will give you your Kinsmans command, Captain of a Troop of Horse-Guards, and which I am sure will be continued to you when the Governour arrives.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I shall endeavour to deserve the Honour, Sir.
sp.stage: Enter Dull. Tim. Whim. and Whiff, all in Buff, Scarf and Feather •…

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: So Gentlemen, I see you're in a readiness.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Readiness! What means he, I hope we are not to be drawn out to go against the Enemy, Major?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: If we are, they shall look a new Major for me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: We were debating, Gentlemen, what course were best to pursue against this Powerful Rebel.

sp.speaker: Frion.
sp.p: Why, Sir, we have Forces enough, let's charge him instantly, delays are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why, what a damn'd fiery Fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: But if we drive him to Extremities, we fear his siding with the Indians.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Collonel Downright has hit it; why should we endanger our Men against a desperate Termagant? If he love Wounds and Scars so well, let him exercise on our Enemies——but if he will needs fall upon us, 'tis then time for us enough to venture our lives and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How, we go to Bacon, under favour I think 'tis his Duty to come to us, an you go to that Gads Zoores.

sp.speaker: Frie.
sp.p: If he do, 'twill cost you dear, I doubt Cornet.—I find by our List, Sir, we are four thousand men.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gads Zoores, not enough for a Breakfast for that insatiate Bacon, and his two Lientenant Generals Fearless and Daring.
sp.stage: [Whiff sits on the ground with a Bottle of Brandy.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: A Morsel, a Morsel.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I am for an attack, what say you Gentlemen to an attack?—What, silent all?—What say you Major?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I say, Sir, I hope my courage was never in dispute. But, Sir, I am going to Marry Collonel Downright's Daughter here—and should I be slain in this Battel 'twou'd break her heart;——besides, Sir, I should lose her Fortune.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I'm sure here's a Captain will never Flinch.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Who I, an't like your Honour?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Ay, you.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Who I? ha, ha, ha,: Why did your Honour think that I would fight?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Fight, yes? Why else do you take Commissions?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Commissions! O Lord, O Lord, take Commissions to fight? ha ha ha; that's a jest, if all that take Commissions should fight—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Why do you bear Arms then?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Why sor the Pay; to be called Captain, noble Captain, to show, to cock and look big and bluff as I do; to be bow'd to thus as we pass, to domineer, and beat our Souldiers: Fight quoth a, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But what makes you look so simply Cornet?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
VVhy a thing that I have quite forgot, all my accounts for England are to be made up, and I'm undone if they be neglected—else
I wou'd not flinch for the stoutest he that wears a Sword—

sp.speaker: Dow'n.
sp.p: VVhat say you Captain Whiff?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: I am trying Collonel what Mettle I'm made on; I think I am Valiant, I suppose I have Courage, but I confess 'tis a little of the D—breed, but a little inspiration from the bottle, and the leave of my Nancy, may do wonders.

sp.speaker: Seam.
sp.p: An't please your Honours, Frightall's Officers have seiz'd all the Ships in the River, and rid now round the Shore, and had by this time secur'd the Sandy Beach, and Landed men to Fire the Town, but that they are high in Drink aboard the Ship call'd the Good Subject; the Master of her sent me to let your Honours know, that a few men sent to his assistance will surprize them, and retake the Ships.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, here's a brave occasion for Emulation—why writ not the Master?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Ay, had he writ, I had soon been amongst them i'faith; but this is some Plot to betray us.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: Keep me here, and kill me if it be not true.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: He says well—there's a Brigan •… ine and a Shallop ready, I'le Embark immediately.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No Sir, your presence is here more necessary, let me have the Honour of this Expedition.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I'le go your Volentier Charles.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: VVho else offers to go.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: A meer trick to Kidnap us, by Bacon,—if the Captain had writ—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Av, ay, if he had writ—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I see you're all base Cowards, and here Cashier ye from all Commands and Offices.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Look ye Collonel, you may do what you please, but you lose one of the best drest Officers in your whole Camp, Sir—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: and in me, such a Head Piece.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: I'le say nothing, but let the State want me.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: For my part I am weary of weighty Affairs.
sp.stage: [In this while VVellman, Down. Friend. and Haz. talk.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Command what Men you please, but Expedition makes you half a Conquerour.
sp.stage: Enter another Seaman with a Letter, gives it to Downright, he and Wellman Read it.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Look ye now Gentlemen the Master has writ.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Has he—he might have writ sooner, while I was in Command,—if he had—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ay Major—if he had—but let them miss us—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p:
Collonel hast with your Men and Reinforce the Beach, while I
follow with the Horse;—Mr. Dunce pray let that Proclamation be Read concerning Bacon, to the Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: It shall be done Sir,
sp.stage: [Exit Down: and Well. The Scene opens and discovers a Body of Souldiers.
sp.p: Gentlemen how simply you look now.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: —VVhy Mr. Parson I have a scruple of Conscience upon me▪ I am considering whether it be Lawful to Kill, tho it be in VVar; I have a great aversion to't, and hope it proceeds from Religion.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: I remember the Fit took you just so, when the Dutch Besieged us, for you cou'd not then be perswaded to strike a stroke.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, that was because they were Protestants as we are, but Gads Zoors had they been Dutch Papists I had maul'd them? but Conscience—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I have been a Justice of Peace this six years and never had a conscience in my Life.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nor I neither, but in this damn'd thing of Fighting.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Gentlemen I am Commanded to read the Declaration of the Honourable Council to you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hum hum hum—

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: Silence—silence—

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: By an order of Council Dated May the 10th 1670: To all Gentlemen Souldiers, Marchants, Planters, and whom else it may concern. VVhereas Bacon, contrary to Law and Equity, has to satisfie his own Ambition taken up Arms, with a pretence to fight the Indians, but indeed to molest and enslave the whole Colony, and to take away their Liberties and Properties; this is to declare, that whoever shall bring this Traytor Dead or alive to the Council shall have three hundred Pounds reward. And so God save the King.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Councel, a Councel! Hah—

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Stand to your Arms Gentlemen, stand to your Arms, Bacon is Marching this way.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Hah—what numbers has he?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.p: About a hundred Horse, in his March he has surpriz'd Collonel Downright, and taken him Prisoner.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Let's fall on Bacon—let's fall on Bacon hay—

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: VVe'll hear him speak first—and see what he can say for himself.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we'l hear Bacon speak—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: VVell Major I have found a Stratagem shall make us four the Greatest Men in the Colony, we'll surrender our selves to Bacon, and say we Disbanded on purpose.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Good—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: VVhy, I had no other design in the VVorld in refusing to •… ight.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Nor I, d'e think I wou'd have excus'd it with the fear of disordering my Cravat String else—

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: VVhy Gentlemen, he designs to Fire James Town; Murder you all, and then lye with your VVives, and will you slip this opportunity of seizing him?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Here's a Tarmagant Rogue Neighbours—we'll Hang the Dog. All, Ay, Ay, hang Bacon, hang Bacon.
sp.stage: Enter Bacon, and Fearless, some Souldiers leading in Downright bound; Bacon stands and stares a while on the Regiments, who are silent all.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: VVell Gentlemen—in order to your fine Declaration you see I come to render my self—

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: How came he to know of our Declaration?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Rogues, Rogues among our selves—that inform.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: VVhat are ye silent all,—not a Man lift his Hand in Obedience to the Council to Murder this Traytor, that has exposed his Life so often for vou? Hah what not for three hundred Pound,—you see I've left my Troops behind, and come all wearied with the Toyles of VVar, worn out by Summers heats and VVinters colds, March'd tedious Days and Nights thro •… ogs and Fens as dangerous as your Clamors, and as Faithless,—what tho 'twas to preserve you all in safety, no matter, you shou'd obey the Grateful Council, and Kill this honest Man that has defended you?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hum, hum hum.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: The General speaks like a Gorgon.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Like a Cherubin, Man.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: All silent yet—where's that mighty Courage that cryed so loud but now? A Council a Council, where is your Resolution, cannot three hundred Pound Excite your Valour, to seize that Traytor Bacon who has bled for you?—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Bacon, a Bacon, a Bacon.—

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Oh Villanous Cowards—Oh the Faithless Multitude!

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: VVhat say you Parson—you have a forward Zeal?

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: I wish my Coat Sir did not hinder me, from acting as becomes my Zeal and Duty.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: A Plaguy Rugid Dog—that Parson—

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Fearless seize me that canting Knave from out the Herd, and next those Honourable Officers.
sp.stage: [Points to Dull. VVhim. VVhiff. and Tim.
Fearless seizes them, and gives them to the Souldiers, and takes the Proclamation from Dunce and shews Bacon, they read it.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Seize us, Sir, you shall not need, we laid down our Commissions on purpose to come over to your Honour.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: We ever lov'd and honour'd your Honour.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: So intirely, Sir—that I wish I were safe in James Town for your sake, and your Honour were hang'd.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
This fine Piece is of your Penning Parson—though it be countenanc'd
by the Councils Names—Oh in gratitude—Burn—Burn the Treacherous Town—Fire it immediately—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: We'll obey you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we'll make a Bonfire on't, and Drink your Honours Health round about it.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Yet hold, my Revenge shall be more Merciful, I ordered that all the Women of Rank shall be seiz'd and brought to my Camp. I'll make their Husbands pay their Ransoms dearly; they'd rather have their Hearts bleed than their Purses.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Dear General, let me have the seizing of Collonel Downright's Daughter; I would fain be Plundering for a Trifle call'd a Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: On pain of Death treat them with all respect; assure them of the safety of their Honour. Now, all that will follow me, shall find a welcom, and those that will not may depart in Peace.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hay, a General, a General, a General.
sp.stage: [Some Souldiers go off, some go to the side of Bacon.
Enter Dareing and Souldiers with Chrisante, Surelove, Mrs. Wnim. and Mrs. Whiff, and several other Women.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Successful Dareing welcome, what Prizes have ye?

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: The Fairest in the VVorld Sir, I'm not for common Plunder.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Hah, my Daughter and my Kinswoman!—

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: 'Tis not with Women Sir, nor honest Men like you that I intend to Combat; not their own Parents shall not be more indulgent, nor better safeguard to their Honours Sir: But 'tis to save the Expence of Blood, I seize on their most valu'd Prizes

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: But Sir, I know your wild Lieutenant General has long lov'd my Chrisante, and perhaps, will take this time to force her to consent.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: I own I have a Passion for Chrisante, yet by my Generals Life—or her fair self—what now I Act is on the score of War, I scorn to force the Maid I do adore.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Believe me Ladies, you shall have Hon ourable Treatment here.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: We do not doubt it Sir, either from you or Dareing, If he Love me——that will secure my Honour, or if he do not, he's to brave to injure me.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: I thank you for your just opinion of me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: But Sir, 'tis for my Father I must plead; to see his Reverend Hands in Serval Chains—and then perhaps if stubborn to your will, his Head must fall a Victim to your Anger.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: No my good Pious Girl, I cannot fear Ignoble usage from the General—And if thy Beauty can preserve thy Fam •… , I shall not mourn in my Captivity.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I'le ne're deceive your kind opinion of me—Ladies I hope you're all of that opinion to.

sp.speaker: —Surel:
sp.p: If seizing us Sir can advance your Honour, or be of any use considerable to you, I shall be proud of such a slavery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Whim.
sp.p: I hope Sir we shan't be Ravish'd in your Camp.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: Fie Mrs. Whimsey, do Souldiers use to Ravish?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Whiff.
sp.p: Ravish—marry I fear 'em not, I'de have em know I scorn to be Ravish'd by any Man!

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Ay a my Conscience Mrs Whiff, you are too good natur'd

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: Madam, I hope: you'l give me leave to name Love to you, and try by all sub misive ways to win your heart?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Do your worst Sir, I give you leave, if you assail me only with your Tongue.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: That's generous and brave, and Ple requite it.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.p: The Truce being ended, Sir, the Indians grow so insolent as to attack us even in our Camp, and have kill'd several of our Men.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: 'Tis time to check their boldness, Dareing haste draw up our Men in order, to give 'em Battel, I rather had expected their submission.
The Country now may see what they're to fear,
Since we that are in Arms are not secure.

div.head: SCENE I. A Temple, with an Indian God placed upon it, Priests and Priestesses attending; Enter Indian King on one side attended by Indian Men, the Queen Enters on the other side with Women, all bow to the Idol, and divide on each side of the Stage, then the Musick Playing lowder, the Priest and Priestesses Dance about the Idol, with ridiculous Postures and crying (as for Incantations.) Thrice repeated, Agah Yerkin, Agah Boah, Sulen Tawarapah, Sulen Tawarapah.
div.stage: After this soft Musick plays again, then they Sing something fine, after which the Priests lead the King to the Altar, and the Priestessess, the Queen, they take off little Crowns from their Heads, and offer them at the Alter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Invoke the God, of our Quiocto to declare, what the Event shall be of this our last War against the English General.
sp.stage: The Musick changes to confused Tunes, to which the Priest and Priestess Dance Antickly Singing between; the same Incantation as before, and then Dance again, and so invoke again alternately: Which Dance ended a Voice behind the Alter cries, while soft Musick Play—

lg.l: The English General shall be,
A Captive to his Enemy;
And you from all your Toyls be freed,
When by your hand the Foe shall bleed
And ere the Sun's swift course be run,
This mighty Conquest, shall be won.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I thank the Gods for taking care of us, prepare new Sacrifice against the Evening, when I return a Conqueror, I will my self perform the Office of a Priest.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I fear you'l fall a Victim first.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What means Semernia, why are thy looks so Pale?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Alas the Oracles have double meanings, their sence is doubtful, and their words Inigma's, I fear Sir I cou'd make a truer interpritation—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How Semernia! by all thy Love I charge thee as you respect my Life, to let me know your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Last Night I Dream'd a Lyon fell with Hunger, spight of your Guards slew you, and bore you hence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This is thy Sexes fear, and no interpretation of the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I cou'd convince you farther.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Hast thou a secret thou canst keep from me? Thy Soul a thought that I must be stranger too? This is not like the Justice of Semernia, come unriddle me the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: The English General shall be, a captive to his Enemy; he is so Sir already to my Beauty, he says he languishes for Love of me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Hah—the General my Rival—but go on—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: And you from all your War be freed: Oh let me not explain that fatal line, for fear it mean, you shall be freed by Death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What, when by my hand the Foe shall bleed?—away——it cannot be—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: No doubt my Lord, you'l bravely sell your Life, and deal some wounds where you'l receive so many.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis Love Semernia makes thee Dream, while waking I'le trust the Gods, and am resolved for Battel.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: Hast, Hast Great Sir to Arms, Bacon with all his Forces is prepar'd, and both the Armies ready to engage.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Hast to my General bid him charge em instantly, I'le bring up the supplys of stout Teroomians, those so well skill'd in the Envenom'd Arrow, [Exit Indian]—Semernia—words but poorly do express
the griefs of parting Lovers—'tis with dying Eyes, and a Heart trembling——thus— [Puts her Hand on his Heart] They take a heavy leave,—one parting Kiss, and one Love pressing sigh, and then farewel—but not a long farewel; I shall return Victorious to thy Arms,—commend me to the Gods and still remember me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Alas! What pitty 'tis I saw the General, before my Fate had given me to the King—but now—like those that change their Gods, my faithless mind 'twixt two opinions wavers; while to the Gods my Monarch I commend; my wandring thoughts in pitty of the General makes that zeal cold, declin'd—ineffectual;—If for the General I, implore the Deieties, methinks my Prayers shou'd not ascend the Skies since Honour tells me 'tis an impious zeal.
Which way so ever my Devotions move,
I am too wretched to be heard above.

div.head: SCENE II. Shows a Field of Tents, seen at some distance thro the Trees of a Wood, Drums, Trumpets and the noise of Battel with hollowing. The Indians are seen with Battle-Axis to Retreat Fighting from the English and all go off, when they Re-enter immediately beating back the English, the Indian King at the head of his Men, with Bows ond Arrows; Dareing being at the head of the English: They Fight off; the noise continues less loud as more at distance.
div.stage: Enter Bacon with his Sword drawn, meets Fearless with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Hast, hast Sir to the Entrance of the Wood, Dareings Engaged past hope of a retreat, ventring too far, persuing of the Foe; the King in Ambush with his Poyson'd Archers, fell on and now we're dangerously distrest.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Dareing is Brave, but, he's withal, too rash, come on and sollow me to his Assistance—
sp.stage: A hollowing within, the Fight renews, Enter the Indians Beaten back by Bacon, Dareing and Fearless, they Fight off, the noise of Fighting continues a while, this still behind the Wood.
Enter Indians Fying over the Stage, pursu'd by the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Turn, turn ye fugitive Slaves, and face the Enemy; Oh Villains, Cowards, Deaf to all Command, by Heaven I had my Rival my in view and Aim'd at nothing but my Conquering him—now like a Coward I must fly with Cowards, or like a desperate Mad-Man fall, thus singly midst the numbers.
sp.stage: Enter Bacon inrag'd with his Sword drawn, Fearless, and Dareing following him.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
—Where is the King, Oh ye perfidious Slaves, how have you
hid from my just Revenge—search all the Brakes, the Fuzes and the Trees; and let him not escape on Pain of Death.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: We cannot do wonders Sir.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: But you can run away—

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: Yes, when we see occasion—yet—shou'd any but my General tell me so——by Heaven he shou'd find I were no starter.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Forgive me, I'm Mad—the Kings escap'd, hid like a trembling slave in some close Ditch, where he will sooner starve than Fight it out.
sp.stage: Re-enter Indians running over the Stage, pursued by the King who shoots them as they Fly, some few follow him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: All's lost—the day is lost—and I'm betray'd—Oh Slaves, that even Wounds can't Animate.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: The King!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The General here, by all the Powers betray'd by my own Men.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Abandon'd as thou art I scorn to take thee basely, you shall have Souldiers chance Sir for your Life, since chance so luckily has brought us hither; without more aids we will dispute the day: this spot of Earth bears both our Armies Fates, I'le give you back the Victory I have won, and thus begin a new, on equal terms.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: That's Nobly said—the Powers have heard my wish! You Sir first taught me how to use a Sword, which heretofore has serv'd me with success, but now—'tis for Semernia that it draws, a prize more valu'd than my Kingdom, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Hah Semernia!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Your Blushes do betray your Passion for her.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: 'Sdeath have we Fought for this, to expose the Victor to the Conquer'd Foe?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: What Fight a single Man—our Prize already.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Not so young Man while I command a Dart.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Fight him, by Heaven no reason shall disswade me, and he that interrupts me is a Coward, whatever be my Fate, I do command ye to let the King pass freely to his Tents.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: The Devils in the General.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: 'Sdeath his Romantick humour will undo us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You Fight as if you meant to outdo me this way, as you have done in Generosity.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You're not behind hand with me Sir in courtesie, come here's to set us even—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You bleed apace.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You've only Breath'd a Vein, and given me new Health and Vigour by it.
sp.stage: [They Fight again, Wounds on both sides, the King staggers, Bacon takes him in his Arms, the King drops his Sword:
sp.p: How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Like one—that's hovering between Heaven and Earth, I'm—mounting—somewhere—upwards—but giddy with my flight,—I know not where.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Command my Surgions,—instantly—make haste Honour returns and Love all Bleeding's fled.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh Semernia, how much more truth had thy Divinity than the Predictions of the flattering Oracles. Commend me to her—I know you'l—visit—your Fair Captive Sir, and tell her—oh—but Death prevents the rest.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: He's gone—and now like Caesar I cou'd weep over the Hero I my self destroy'd.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: I'm glad for your repose I see him there—'twas a Mad hot Brain'd Youth and so he dy'd.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Come bear him on your Shoulders to my Tent, from whence with all the solemn state we can, we will convey him to his own Pavillion.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Some of our Troops pursuing of the Enemy even to their Temples, which they made their Sanctuary, finding the Queen at her Devotion there with all her Indian Ladies, I'd much ado to stop their violent rage from setting fire to the Holy Pile.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Hang em immediately that durst attempt it, while I my self will flye to rescue her.
sp.stage: [Goes out, they bear off the Kings Body, Ex. all.
Enter Whimsey pulling in Whiff, with a Halter about his Neck.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Nay I'm resolv'd to keep thee here till his Honour the General comes,—what to call him Traytor, and run away after he had so generously given us our freedom, and Listed us Cadees for the next command that fell in his Army;—I'm resolv'd to Hang thee—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Wilt thou betray and Peach thy Friend: Thy Friend that kept thee Company all the while thou wert a Prisoner—Drinking at my own charge.—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: No matter for that, I scorn Ingratitude and therefore will Hang thee—but as for thy drinking with me—I scorn to be hehind hand with thee in Civility and therefore here's to thee.
sp.stage: [Takes a Bottle of Brandy out of his Pocket, Drinks.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: I can't drink.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: A certain sign thou wo't be Hang'd.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: You us'd to be a my side when a Justice, set the cause be how it wou'd.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ay—when I was a Justice I never minded Honesty, but now I'le be true to my General, and Hang thee to be a great man.—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: If I might but have a fair Tryal for my Life—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: A fair Tryal—come I'le be thy Judge—and if thou can'st clear thy self by Law I'le acquit thee, Sirrah, Sirrah, what can'st thou say for thy self for calling his Honour Rebel?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: 'Twas when I was Drunk an't like yourHonour.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: That's no Plea, for if you kill a Man when you are Sober you must be Hang'd when you are Drunk, hast thou any thing else to say for thy self, why Sentence may not pass upon thee?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: I desire the Benefit of the Clergy.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: The Clergy, I never knew any body that ever did benefit by em, why thou canst not read a word?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Transportation then—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: It shall be to England then—but hold—who's this?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: So the dangers over, I may venture out,—Pox on't I would not be in this fear again, to be Lord Chief Justice of our Court. Why how now Cornet—what in dreadful Enter Timerous with Battle Ax, Bow and Arrows, and Feathers on his Head. Equipage? Your Battle Ax Bloody, with Bow and Arrows?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'm in the posture of the times Major—I cou'd not be Idle where so much Action was, I'm going to present my self to the General with these Trophies of my Victory here—

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Victory—what Victory—did not see thee creeping out of yonder Bush, where thou weret hid all the Fight—stumble on a Dead Indian, and take away his Arms?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why, didst thou see me?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: See thee Ay—and what a fright thou wert in, till thou wert sure he was Dead.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well, well, that's all one—Gads zoors if every Man that pass for Valiant in a Battel, were to give an account how he gain'd his Reputation, the World wou'd be but thinly stock'd with Heroes, I'le say he was a great War Captain, and that I kill'd him hand to hand, and who can disprove me?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Disprove thee—why that Pale face of thine, that has so much of the Coward in't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Shaw that's with loss of Blood—Hah I am overheard I doubt—who's yonder— [Sees Whim. and Whiff.] how Brother Whiff in a Hempen Cravat-String?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: He call'd the General Traytor and was running away, and-I'm resolved to Peach.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Hum—and one witness will stand good in Law, in case of Treason—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Gads zoors in case of Treason he'l beHang'd if it be proved against
him, were there ne're a witness at all, but he must try'd by a Councel of War Man—come, come let's disarm him—
sp.stage: [They take away his Arms, and pull a Bottle of Brandy out of his Pocket.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: What, I hope you will not take away my Brandy Gentlemen, my last comfort.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gads zoors it's come in good time—we'l Drink it off, here Major—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Hark ye Cornet—you are my good Friend, get this matter made up before it come to the General.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: But this is Treason Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: If I Hang—I'le declare upon the Ladder, how you kill'd your War Captain

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come Brother Whimsey—we have been all Friends and loving Magistrates together, let's Drink about, and think no more of this business.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Ay, ay, if every sober man in the Nation, should be call'd to account of the Treason he speaks in's Drink the Lord have mercy upon us all—put it up—and let us like loving Brothers take an honest resolution to run away together; for this same Frightal minds nothing but Fighting.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I'm content, provided we go all to the Council and tell them (to make our Peace) we went in obedience to the Proclamation to kill Bacon, but the Traytor was so strongly guarded we could not effect it, but Mum—who's here—
sp.stage: [To them, Enter Ranter and Jenny, as Man and Footman.

sp.speaker: -Rant.
sp.p: Hah, our four Reverend Justices—I hope the Blockheads will not know me—Gentlemen, can you direct me to Lieutenant General Dareings Tents.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Hum, who the Devil's this—that's he that you see coming this way, 'Sdeath yonders Dareing—Let's slip away before he advances.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I am scar'd with those dead Bodies we have past over, for God's sake Madam, let me know your design in coming.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Why? now I'le tell thee—my damn'd mad Fellow Dareing who has my heart and soul—Loves Chrisante, has stolen her, and carryed her away to his Tents, she hates him, while I am dying for him.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Dying Madam! I never saw you melancholy.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Pox on't no, why should I sigh and whine, and make my self an Ass. and him conceited, no, instead of snevelling I'm resolv'd—

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: What Madam?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Gad to beat the Rascal, and bring of Crisante.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Beat him Madam? What a woman beat a Lieutenant General.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p:
Hang 'em, they get a name in War, from command, not courage; how know I but I may fight, Gad I have known a Fellow kickt
from one end of the Town to t'other, believing himself a Coward, at last forc'd to fight, found he could, got a Reputation and bullyed all he met with, and got a name, and a great Commission.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: But if he should kill you Madam?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: I'le take care to make it as Comical a Duel as the best of 'em, as much in Love as I am, I do not intend to dy it's Martyr.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Have you seen Crysante since the fight?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Yes, but she is still the same, as nice and coy as Fortune, when she's courted by the wretched, yet she denys me, so obligingly she keeps my Love still in its humble Calm.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Can you direct me Sir, to one Dareings Tent:

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: One Dareing—he has another Epithet to his name?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: What's that, Rascal, or Coward?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Hah, which of thy Stars young man has sent thee hither, to find that certain Fate they have decreed.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I know not what my Stars have decreed, but I shall be glad if they have ordain'd me to Fight with Dareing,—by thy concern thou shou'dst be he?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I am, prithee who art thou?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Thy Rival, tho newly arriv'd from England, and came to Marry fair Chrisante, whom thou hast Ravish'd, for whom I hear another Lady Dies.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Dies for me?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Therefore resign her fairly—or fight me fairly—

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Come on Sir—but hold—before I kill thee, prithee inform me who this Dying Lady is?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Sir I owe ye no Courtesie, and therefore will do you none by telling you—come Sir for Chrisante—draws.
sp.stage: [They offer to Fight Fearless steps in.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Hold—what mad Frolicks this?—Sir you Fight for one you never saw [to Ranter] and you for one that Loves you not. [To Dare.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Perhaps she'l Love him as little.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Gad put it to the Tryal, if you dare—if thou be'st Generous bring me to her, and whom she does neglect shall give the other Place.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: That's fair put up thy Sword—I'le bring thee to her Instantly.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I'm not so much afflicted for my confinement as I am, that I cannot hear of Friendly.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: Art not persecuted with Dareing?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Not at all, tho he tells me daily of his Passion I rally him, and give him neither hope nor despair,—he's here.
sp.stage: Enter Dareing Fear. Rant. and Jenny.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: Madam, the Complaisance I show in bringing you my Rival, will let you see how glad I am to oblige you every way.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I hope the danger I have expos'd my self too for the Honour of kissing your hand Madam, will render me something acceptable—here are my Credentials—

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Dear Creature, I have taken this habit to free you from an impertinent Lover, and to secure the Damn'd Rogue Dareing to my self, receive me as sent by Collonel Surelove from England to Marry you—favour me—no more—your Ranter—Hah Ranter? [Aside]—Sir you have too good a Character from my Cousin Collonel Surelove, not to receive my welcome.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Stand by General—
sp.stage: [Pushes away Dareling and looks big, and takes Chrisante by the hand and kisses it.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: 'Sdeath Sir there's room—enough—at first sight so kind? Oh Youth—Youth and Impudence, what Temptations are you—to Villanous Woman.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I confess Sir we Women do not Love these rough Fighting Fellows, they're always scaring us with one Broil or other.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Much good may do you with your tame Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Well Sir, then you yield the Prize?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Ay Gad, were she an Angel, that can prefer such a callow Fop as thou before a man—take her and domineer.
—'Sdeath am I grown Ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Why hast thou not found the Jest? by Heaven 'tis Ranter, 'tis she that loves you, carry on the humour. (aside.) Faith Sir, if I were you, I would devote my self to Madam Ranter.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Ay, she's the fittest Wife for you, she'll fit your Humour.

sp.speaker: Dar. and Ranter
sp.p: —Gad I'd sooner marry a She Bear, unless for a Pennance for some horrid Sin, we should be eternally challenging one another to the Field, and ten to one she beats me there; or if I should escape there, she would kill me with Drinking.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Here's a Rogue—does your Country abound with such Ladies?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: The Lord forbid, half a dozen wou'd ruine the Land, debauch all the men, and scandalize all the women.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: No matter, she's rich.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Ay that will make her Insolent.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Nay she's generous too.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Yes when she's Drunk, and then she'l lavish all.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: A Pox on him—how he vexes me.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Then such a Tongue—she'l rail and smoak till she choak again then six Gallons of Punch hardly recovers her, and never but then is she' good Natur'd.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I must lay him on—

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: There's not a Blockhead in the Country that has not—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: —What—

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: —Been Drunk with her.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I thought you had meant something else Sir.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Nay—as for that—I suppose there's no great difficulty.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: 'Sdeath Sir you lye—and you're a Son of a Whore.
sp.stage: [Draws and Fences with him, and he runs back round the Stage.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Hold—hold Virago—dear Widow hold, and give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Widow!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: 'Sdeath I knew thee by instinct Widow tho I seem'd not to do so, in revenge for the trick you put on me in telling me a Lady dy'd for me.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Why, such an one there is, perhaps she may dwindle forty or fifty years—or so—but will never be her own Woman again that's certain.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: This we are all ready to testifie, we know her.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Upon my Life tis true.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Widow I have a shrewd suspicion, that you your self may be this dying Lady.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Why so Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Because you took such pains to put your self into my hands.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Gad if your heart were but half so true as your guess, we should conclude a Peace before Bacon and the Council will—besides this thing whines for Friendly and there's no hopes.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Give me thy hand Widow, I am thine—and so intirely, I will never—be drunk out of thy Company—Dunce is in my Tent—prithee let's in and bind the bargain.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay, faith, let's see the Wars at an end first.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, take me in the humour, while thy Breeches are on—for I never lik'd thee half so well in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Lead on General, you give me good incouragement to wear them.

div.head: SCENE I. The Sevana in sight of the Camp; the Moon rises. Enter Friendly, Hazard and Boozer, and a Party of Men.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: WE we are now in the sight of the Tents.

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: Is not this a rash attempt, Gentlemen, with so small Force to set upon Bacons whole Army?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Oh, they are drunk with Victory and Wine; there will be naught but Revelling to Night.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Would we cou'd learn in wha Quarter the Ladies are lodg'd, for we have no other business but to release them—but hark—who comes here?

sp.speaker: Booz.
sp.p: Some Scouts, I fear, from the Enemy.
sp.stage: Enter Dullman, Tim. Whim. and Whiff, creeping as in the dark.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Let's shelter our selves behind yonder Trees—lest we be surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Wou'd I were well at home—Gad Zoors—if e're you catch me a Cadeeing again, I'll be content to be set in the fore front of the Battel for Hawks Meat.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Thou'rt affraid of every Bush.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, and good Reason too: Gad Zoors, there may be Rogues hid—prithee Major, do thou advance.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: No, no, go on—no matter of ceremony in these cases of running away.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: They approach directly to us, we cannot escape them—their numbers are not great—let us advance.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Oh, I am annihilated.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Some of Frightall's Scouts; we are lost men.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Oh, they'll give us no Quarter; 'twas long of you Cornet, that we ran away from our Colours.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Me—'twas the Majors Ambition here—to make himself a great Man with the Council again.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Poxo' this Ambition, it has been the ruin of many a Gallant Fellow.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: If I get home again, the height of mine shall be to top Tobacco; would l'd some Brandy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gads Zoors, would we had, 'tis the best Armour against fear—hum—I hear no body now—prithee advance a little.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: What, before a Horse Officer?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Stand on your Lives—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis impossible—I am dead already.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: What are ve—speak—or I'll shoot?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Friends to thee—who the Devil are we friends too?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: E'ne who you please, Gad Zoors.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Hah—Gad Zoors—who's there, Timerous?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hum—I know no such Scoundrel—

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Hah—that's Friendly's Voice.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Right—thine's that of Dullman—who's with you?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Only Timerous, Whimsey and Whiff, all Valiantly running away from the Arch Rebel that took us Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Can you inform us where the Ladies are lodg'd?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: In the hither Quarter in Dareings Tents; you'll know them by Lanthorns on every corner—there was never better time to surprize them—for this day Dareing's Marry'd, and there's nothing but Dancing and Drinking.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Married! To whom?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: That I ne'r inquir'd.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: 'Tis to Crisante, Friend—and the reward of my attempt is lost. Oh, I am mad, I'll fight away my life, and my dispair shall yet do greater wonders, than even my Love could animate me too. Let's part our Men, and beset his Tents on both sides.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, let's on—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: On Sir—we on Sir?—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Ay, you on, Sir—to redeem the Ladies

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I am going home for money to redeem my Nancy.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: So am I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I thank my Stars I am a Batchellor—Why, what a plague is a Wife?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Will you March forward?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: We have atchiev'd Honour enough already, in having made our Campaign-here—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, but you shall go—put them in the front, and prick them on—if they offer to turn back run them through.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Oh, horrid—
sp.stage: [The Souldiers prick them on with their Swords.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Oh, Nancy, thy Dream will yet come to pass.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Will you advance, Sir?

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Why, so we do, Sir; the Devil's in these fighting Fellows.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: To Arms, to Arms, the Enemy's upon us.
sp.stage: A noise of fighting, after which enters Friendly with his Party, retreating and fighting, from Dareing and some Souldiers, Ranter fighting like a Fury by his side, he putting her back in vain; they fight out. Re-enter Daring with Friendly all bloody. Several Souldiers enter with Flambeaux.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Now, Sir—what injury have I ever done you, that you should use this Treachery against me?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: To take advantage any way in War, was never counted Treachery—and had I Murder'd thee, I had not paid thee half the Debt I owe thee.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: You bleed too much to hold too long a Parley—come to my Tent, I'll take a charitable care of thee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I scorn thy Courtesie, who against all the Laws of Honour and of Justice, hast ravish'd innocent Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Sir, your upbraiding of my Honour shall never make me forfeit it, or esteem you less—Is there a Lady here you have a Passion for?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Yes, on a Nobler score than thou darest own.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: To let you see how you're mistaken, Sir, who e're that Lady be whom you affect, I will resign, and give you both your Freedoms.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Why, for this Courtesie, which shows thee brave, in the next Fight I'le save thy Life, to quit the obligation.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir—come to my Tent—and when we've drest your Wounds, and yielded up the Ladies, I'll give you my Passport for your safe conduct back, and tell your Friends i'th' Town we'll Visit them i'th' Morning.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: They'll meet you on your way, Sir—

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Come, my young Souldier, now thou'st won my Soul.
sp.stage: An Alarm beats: Enter at another passage Boozer with all the Ladies; they pass over the Stage, while Hazard, Downright, beating back a Party of Souldiers. Dull. Tim. Whim and Whiff, prickt on by their Party to fight, so that they lay about them like Madmen. Bacon, Fearless and Dareing come in, rescue their men, and fight out the other Party, some falling dead. Bacon, Fearless and Dareing return tired, with their Swords drawn. Ent •… Souldier running.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: Return, Sir, where your Sword will be more useful—a Party of Indians, taking advantage of the Night, have set Fire on your Tents, and born away the Queen.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Hah, the Queen! By Heaven this Victory shall cost them dear; come, let us fly to rescue her.
sp.stage: Enter Wellman, Brag, Grub and Officers.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I cannot sleep my Impatience is so great, to ingage this haughty Enemy, before they have reposed their weary Limbs—Is not you Ruddy Light the Mornings Dawn.

sp.speaker: Bragg.
sp.p: 'Tis, and please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Is there no News of Friendly yet, and Hazard?

sp.speaker: Bragg.
sp.p: Not yet—'tis thought they left the Camp to Night, with some design against the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What Men have they?

sp.speaker: Bragg.
sp.p: Only Boozers Party, Sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I know they are brave, and mean to surprize me with some handsom Action.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I ask a thousand Pardons, Sir, for quitting the Camp without your leave.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Your Conduct and your Courage cannot Err; I see thou'st been in action by thy Blood.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Sir I'm ashamed to own these slender wounds, since without more my luck was to be taken, while Hazard did alone effect the business; the rescuing of the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: How got ye Liberty?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: By Dareings generosity, who sends you word he'l visit you this Morning.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: We are prepared to meet him.
sp.stage: Enter Downright, Hazard, Ladies, Whim. Whiff, Dullman, Tim. looking big; Well. Embraces Down.—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: My worthy Friend how am I joyed to see you?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: We owe our Liberties to these brave Youths, who can do wonders when they Fight for Ladies.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: With our assistance Ladies.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: For my part I'le not take it as I have done, Gad I find when I am Damnable Angry I can beat both Friend and Foe.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: When I fight for my Nancy here—adsfish I'm a Dragon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Whiff.
sp.p: Lord you need not have been so hasty:

sp.speaker: Frien.
sp.p: Do not upbraid me with your Eyes Chrisante, but let these wounds assure you I endeavour'd to serve you, tho Hazard had the Honour on't.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: But Ladies we'l not expose you in the Camp,—a Party of our Men shall see you safely conducted to Madam Sureloves; 'tis but a little Mile from our Camp.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Let me have that Honour Sir.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: No, I conjure you let your wounds be drest, obey me if you Love me, and Hazard shall conduct us home.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: He had the Toyl, 'tis fit he have the recompence.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: He the Toyl Sir, what did we stand for Cyphers?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: The very appearance I made in the front of the Battle, aw'd the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Let the Enemy say how I maul'd 'em—but Gads zoors I scorn to brag.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Since you've regain'd your Honour so Gloriously—I restore you to your Commands, you lost by your seeming Cowardise.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Valour is not always in Humour Sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen since they're resolv'd to engage us, let's set our Men in order to receive 'em.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Our Commissions again—you must be bragging, and see what comes on't; I was modest ye see and said nothing of my Prowess.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: What a Devil, does the Collonel think we are made of Iron, continually to be beat on the Anvil?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Look Gentlemen here's two Evils—if we go we are dead Men if we stay we are hang'd—and that will disorder my Cravat-string—therefore the least Evil is to go—and set a good Face on the matter as I do—
sp.stage: SCENE a thick Wood, Enter Queen drest like an Indian Man, with a Bow in her hand and Quiver at her Back, Anaria her Confident disguis'd so too, and about a Duzen Indians led by Cavaro.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: I tremble yet, dost think we're safe Cavaro.

sp.speaker: Cav.
sp.p: Madam these Woods are intricate and vast; and 'twill be difficult to find us out—or if they do, this habit will secure you from the fear of being taken.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Dost think if Bacon find us he will not know me? Alas my fears and blushes will betray me.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Tis certain Madam if we stay we Perish; for all the Wood's surrounded by the Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Alas 'tis better we shou'd Perish here, than stay to expect the violence of his Passion; Towhich my heart's too sensibly inclin'd.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Why do you not obey it's dictates then, why do you fly the Conqueror?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Not fly—not fly the Murderer of my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: VVhat world, what resolution can preserve you, and what he cannot gain by soft submission, force will at last o'recome.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: I wish there were in Nature one excuse either by force or Reason to compel me:—For oh Anaria—I adore this General,—take from my Soul a Truth—till now conceal'd—at twelve years Old—at the Pauwmungian Court I saw this Conqueror. I saw him young and Gay as new born Spring, Glorious and Charming as the Mid-days Sun, I watch't his looks, and listned when he spoke, and thought him more than Mortal.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: He has a graceful Form.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: At last a Fatal Match concluded was, between my Lord and me I gave my Hand, but oh how far my heart was from consenting, the angry Gods are witness.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: 'Twas pity.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p:
Twelve teadious Moons I past in silent languishment; Honour endeavouring to destroy my Love, but all in vain, for still my pain return'd when ever I beheld my Conqueror, but now when I consider him
as Murderer of my Lord—[Feircely] I sigh and wish—some other fatal hand had given him his Death—but now there's a necessity I must be brave and overcome my Heart: VVhat if I do? ah whether shall I fly, I have no Amazonian fire about me, all my Artillery is sighs and Tears, the Earth my Bed, and Heaven my Canopy.
Hah, we are surpris'd, oh whether shall I fly? And yet methinks a certain trembling joy, spight of my Soul, spight of my boasted Honour, runs shivering round my heart..

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: Madam your out guards are surpriz'd by Bacon, who hews down all before him, and demands the Queen with such a voice and Eyes so Feirce and Angry, he kills us with his looks.

sp.speaker: Cav.
sp.p: Draw up your Poyson'd Arrows to the head, and aim them at his Heart, sure some will hit.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Cruel Cavaro,—wou'd 'twere fit for me to contradict thy Justice.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: The Queen ye slaves, give me the Queen and live!
sp.stage: He Enters furiously beating back some Indians, Cavaro's Party going to shoot, the Queen runs in.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I do Command ye [Bac. Flys on em as they shoot and miss him, and fights like a fury, and wounds the Queen in the disorder; beats them all out.—hold thy commanding Hand, and do not kill me, who wou'd not hurt thee to regain my Kingdom—
sp.stage: [He snatches her in his Arms she reels.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Hah—a Womans Voice,—what art thou? Oh my fears!

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Thy hand has been too cruel to a Heart—whose Crime was only tender thoughts for thee.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: The Queen! VVhat is't my Sacreligious hand has done?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: The noblest office of a Gallant Friend, thou'st sav'd my Honour and hast given me Death.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Is't possible! ye unregarding Gods is't possible?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Now I may Love you without Infamy, and please my Dying Heart by gazing on you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Oh I am lost—for ever lost—I find my Brain turn with the wild confusion.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: I faint—oh lay me gently on the Earth.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Who waits— [Turns in rage to his Men.] make of the Trophies of the War a Pile, and set it all on Fire, that I may leap into consuming. Flames—while all my Tents are burning round about me. [VVildly Oh thou dear Prize for which alone I Toyl'd.
sp.stage: Enter Fearless with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Hah on the Earth—how do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: What wou'dst thou?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Wellman with all the Forces he can gather attacks us even in our very Camp, assist us Sir or all is lost.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Why prithee let him make the World his Prize, I have no business with the Trifle now; it now contains nothing that's worth my case, since my fair Queen—is Dead,—and by my Hand.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: So charming and obliging is thy mone, that I cou'd wish for Life to recompence it; but oh, Death falls—all cold—upon my Heart like Mildews on the Blossoms.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: By Heaven Sir, this Love will ruin all—rise, rise and save us yet.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Leave me, what e're becomes of me—loose not thy share of Glory—prithee leave me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Alas, I fear, thy Fate is drawing on, and I shall shortly meet thee in the Clouds; till then—farewel—even Death is pleasing to me, while thus—I find it in thy Arms—

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: There ends my Race of Glory and of Life:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Hah—Why should I idly whine away my life, since there are Nobler ways to meet with Death?—Up, up, and face him then—Hark—there's the Souldiers knell—and all the Joys of Life—with thee I bid farewel—
sp.stage: [Goes out. The Indians bear off the Body of the Queen.
The Alarm continues: Enter Downright, Wellman, and others, Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: They fight like men possest—I did not think to have found them so prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: They'ye good intelligence—but where's the Rebel?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sure he's not in the fight, oh that it were my happy chance to meet him, that while our men look on, we might dispatch the business of the War.—Come, let's fall in again now we have taken breath.
sp.stage: They go out: Enter Dareing and Fearless hastily, with their Swords drawn, meet Whim, Whiff, with their Swords drawn, running away.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: How now, whether away?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Hah, Dareing here—we are pursuing of the Enemy, Sir, stop us not in the pursuit of Glory.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Stay—I have not seen you in my ranks to day.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Lord, does your Honour take us for Starters?

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Yes, Sirrah, and believe you are now rubbing off—confess, or I'll run you through.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Oh Mercy, Sir, Mercy, we'll confese.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: VVhat will you confess—we were only going behind you Hedge to untruss a point; that's all.

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Ay, your Honours will smell out the truth if you keep us here long.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Here, carry themPrisoners to my Tent, [Ex Sould with Wh. & Whiff.

A Pox of all ill luck, how came •… to •… ese Dareing in the fight?
Ha—who's here?—Dullman and Timerous Dead—the Rogues are Counterfeits—I'll see what Moveables they have about them, all's Lawful Prize in VVar.
sp.stage: [Takes their Money, Watches and Rings: goes out.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: VVhat, Rob the Dead?—VVhy, what will this Villanous World come to.
sp.stage: [Clashing of Swords just as they were going to rise.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Thou cou'dst expect no other Fate Young man, thy hands are yet too tender for a Sword.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Thou look'st like a good natur'd Fellow, use me civilly, and Dareing shall Ransom me.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Doubt not a Generous Treatment.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: So, the Coast is clear, I desire to remove my Quarters to some place of more safety——

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: 'Twas this way Bacon fled. [Enter Wellman and Souldiers hastily. five hundred pound for him who finds the Rebel.
sp.stage: Scene changes to a Wood: Enter Bacon and Fearless, with their Swords drawn, all bloody.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: 'Tis Just, ye Gods! That when you took the Prize for which I fought, Fortune and you should all abandon me.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Oh fly Sir to some place of safe retreat, for there's no mercy to be hop't if taken. What will you do, I know we are pursu'd, by Heaven I will not dye a shameful Death.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Oh they'll have pitty on thy Youth and Bravery, but I'm above their Pardon.
This way—this way—hay—hallow.

sp.speaker: Fear.
sp.p: Alas Sir we're undone—I'll see which way they they take.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: So near! Nay then to my last shift. Undoes the Pomel of his Sword. Come my good Poyson, like that of Hannibal, long I have born a noble Remedy for all the ills of Life. Takes Poyson. I have too long surviv'd my Queen and Glory, those two bright Stars that influenc'd my Life are set to all Eternity.
sp.stage: Enter Fearless, runs to Bacon and looks on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: —Hah—what have ye done?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Secur'd my self from being a publick Spectacle upon the common Theatre of Death.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Victory, victory, they fly, they fly, where's the Victorious General?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Here—taking his last Adieu.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: Dying? Then wither all the Laurels on my Brows, for I shall never Triumph more in War, where is the wounds?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: From his own hand by what he carried here, believing we had lost the Victory.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: And is the Enemy put to flight my Hero?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: All routed Horse and Foot, I plac'd an Ambush, and while they were pursuing you, my Men fell on behind and won the day.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Thou almost makes me wish to Live again, If I cou'd live now Fair Semernia's Dead,—But oh—the baneful Drug is just and kind and hastens me away—now while you are Victors make a Peace—with the English Councel—and never let Ambition—Love—or Interest make you forget as I have done—your Duty—and Allegiance—farewel—a long farewel—

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: So fell the Roman Cassius—by mistake—
sp.stage: Enter Souldiers with Dunce, Tim. and Dullman.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: An't please your Honour we took these Men running away.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Let 'em loose—the VVars are at an end, see where the General lyes—that great Soul'd Man, no private Body e're contain'd a Nobler, and he that cou'd have conquer'd all America, finds only here his scanty length of Earth,—go bear the Body to his own Pavillion— [Souldiers goes out with the Body] Tho we are Conquerers we submit to treat, and yeild upon conditions, you Mr. Dunce shall bear our Articles to the Councel—

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: VVith joy I will obey you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Good General let us be put in the agreement.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: You shall be oblig'd—
sp.stage: [Ex. Dar. Dunc. Dull. and Tim. as Fear. goes out, a Souldier meets him

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p: VVhat does your Honour intend to do with Whim and Whiff, who are Condemn'd by a Councel of VVar.
sp.stage: Enter Dareing, Dullman Tim. Fearless and Officers.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: You come too late Gentlemen to be put into the Articles, nor am I satisfy'd you're worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: VVhy did not you Sir see us ly Dead in the Field.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Yes, but I see no wound about you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: VVe were stun'd with being knock'd down, Gads zoors a Man may be kill'd with the But end of a Musquet, as soon as with the point of a Sword.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: The Council Sir wishes you Health and Happiness, and •… sends you these Sign'd by their Hands—

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: That you shall have a general Pardon for your self and Friends, that you shall have all new Commissions, and Dareing to Command as General; that you shall have free leave to Inter •… your Dead General, in James Town, and to ratifie this—we will meet you at Madam Sureloves House which stands between the Armies, attended by only by our Officers. The Councels noble and I'le wait upon them.
sp.stage: SCENE a Grove near Madam Sureloves, Enter Surelove weeping, VVell. Crisante, Mrs. Flirt, Ranter as before, Down. Haz. Frien. Booz. Brag.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: How long Madam have you heard the news of Collonel Su •… ve's Death?

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: By a Vessel last Night arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You shou'd not grieve when men so old pay their debt to Nature, you are too Fair not to have been reserved for some young Loves Arms.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I dare not speak—but give me leave to hope.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: The way to oblige me to't, is never more to speak to me of Love till I shall think it fit—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Come you shan't grant it—'tis a hopeful Youth.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: You are too much my Friend to be deny'd—Crisante do you Love Friendly? nay do not blush—till you have done a fault, your Loving him is none—here take her young Man and with her all my Fortune—when I am Dead Sirrah—not a Groat before—unless to buy ye Baby Clouts.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: He merits not this Treasure Sir, can wish for more.
sp.stage: Enter Dareing, Fearless, Dunce and Officers, they meet VVell: and Down. who Embrace em. Dull. and Tim. stand.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Can you forgive us Sir our disobedience.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Your offering peace while yet you might command it, has made such kind impressions on us, that now you may command your Propositions; your Pardons are all Seal'd and new Commissions.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: I'm not Ambitious of that Honour Sir, but in obedience will accept your goodness, but Sir I hear I have a young Friend taken Prisoner by Captain Hazard whom I intreat you'l render me,

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Sir—here I resign him to you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Faith General you left me but scurvily in Battel.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: That was to see how well you cou'd shift for your self, now I find you can bear the brunt of a Campaign you are a fit VVife for a Souldier.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A VVoman—Ranter—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Faith Madam I shou'd have given you kinder. Quarter if I had known my Happiness.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: I have an humble Petition to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sure.
sp.p: In which we all joyn.

sp.speaker: Flir.
sp.p: An't please you Sir, Mr. Dunce has long made Love to me and on promise of Marriage has—

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: VVhat has he Mrs. Flirt.

sp.speaker: Flir.
sp.p: Only been a little familiar with my Person Sir—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Do you hear Parson—you must Marry Mrs. Flirt.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: How Sir, a Man of my Coat Sir, Marry a Brandy-munger.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Of your calling you mean a Farrier and no Parson— [Aside to him] she'l leave her Trade—and spark it above all the Ladies at Church, no more—take her and make her honest.

sp.speaker: Crys.
sp.p: Bless me, what have we here?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Why, an't like your Honours, we were taken by the Enemy.—hah Dareing here and Fearless?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: How now—Gentlemen were not you two Condemn'd to be Shot for running from your Colours.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: From your Colours.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.p: Yes Sir, they were both listed in my Regiment.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Then we must hang them for deserting us.

sp.speaker: VVhim.
sp.p: So out of the Frying Pan—you know where Brother—

sp.speaker: Whiff.
sp.p: Ay—he that's Born to be Hang'd—you know the rest, a Pox of these Proverbs.

sp.speaker: VVell.
sp.p: I know ye well—you're all rank Cowards, but once more we forgive ye, your Places in the Councel shall be supply'd by these Gentlemen of Sence and Honour. The Governour when he comes shall find the Country in better hands than he expects to find it.

sp.speaker: VVhim.
sp.p: A very fair discharge,

sp.speaker: VVhiff.
sp.p: I'm glad 'tis no worse, I'le home to my Nancy.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Have we expos'd our Lives and Fortunes for this?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gads zoors I never thriv'd since I was a States-man, left Planting, and fell to promising and Lying, I'le to my old Trade again, bask under the shade of my own Tobacco, and Drink my Punch in Peace.

sp.speaker: VVell.
sp.l: Come my brave Youths let all our Forces meet,
To make this Country Happy, Rich, and great;
Let scanted Europe see that we enjoy
Safer Repose, and larger Worlds than they.
